ARTICLE F. 911 COORDINATOR
1-8F-1: POSITION CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the position of 911 coordinator who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
1-8F-2: NARRATIVE OF POSITION:
A. The 911 coordinator is a full time, nonunion, salaried position, working forty (40) hours, Monday
through Friday, eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
B. The 911 coordinator shall report directly to the chief of police but shall also be under the auspices
of the mayor, the city administrator, the police/fire commissioner as well as the joint emergency
telephone systems board (JETSB). (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
C. The 911 coordinator shall work with the police department's communications supervisor in order to
create the smoothest operating facility possible under all types of conditions. The 911 coordinator
shall also work with: (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
1. The JETSB to implement and maintain goals and objectives related to the city's 911 system.
(Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2. The PSAP (public safety answering points) to assure an efficient and effective 911 system.
3. All citywide emergency services agencies (police, fire, ambulance) to meet their needs.
4. The citizens of the city in order to educate and better inform them about the 911 system. (Ord.
3030, 1-9-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 29/460
1-8F-3: DUTIES:
The duties of the 911 coordinator shall include, but not be limited to:
A. Coordinate with city hall, including the water and street departments, with regards to mapping
issues and the naming of streets.
B. Maintain all aspects of the 911 geographic information system (GIS). (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
C. Prepare and maintain the official records of the JETSB.
D. Attend JETSB meetings, special meetings, and committee meetings; issue meeting notices; and
take and distribute minutes of meetings. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
E. Coordinate public awareness and public relations activities to include programs and presentations
about the enhanced 911 system and conduct educational programs for schoolchildren and/or
school districts. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
F. Draft an annual budget with the assistance and guidance of the JETSB; work with the city finance
director-treasurer's office to monitor cash flow; and advise the JETSB on budgetary impacts. (Ord.
3030, 1-9-2012; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
G. Maintain an inventory of all JETSB owned equipment and relay same to the city clerk for inclusion
in the overall city inventory.
H. Keep up to date manuals for all JETSB owned equipment; test PSAP equipment; and coordinate
with the chief of police, or his designee, the repair or replacement of all JETSB owned equipment.
(Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
I. Perform periodic random testing of the 911 system, including call overflow. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
J. Negotiate, monitor and manage JETSB contracts and purchases as directed. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012;
amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
K. Maintain an accurate database for the population being served.
L. Maintain an accurate listing of emergency service providers and emergency service number (ESN)
boundaries, including all police, fire and emergency medical service (EMS) providers and provide
updates to all PSAPs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 30/460
M. Maintain an accurate listing of contact persons, addresses and phone numbers for each police, fire
and emergency medical service (EMS) provider and provide any updates to all PSAPs. (Ord. 3030,
1-9-2012)
N. Report to the JETSB regarding any problems, policies or other matters pertinent to the board. (Ord.
3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
O. Work with Marion citizens and businesses to ensure address numbers are both visible and legible
to emergency services.
P. Provide reports to the city council regarding activity, equipment, problems or information as
necessary or requested. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
Q. Act as the JETSB's liaison with the telephone companies (or other service providers); the ICC
(Illinois commerce commission); each participating governmental agency; emergency service
providers; equipment maintenance contractors; and the public. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord.
3271, 8-10-2015)
R. Respond to complaints, questions and/or inquiries from the public in a timely manner.
S. Conduct critiques, prepare reports and make recommendations to the chief of police to ensure any
issues are resolved.
T. Remain current in new trends of emergency communications and 911. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
U. Attend approved meetings and/or conferences of affiliated associations such as Marion's JETSB
representative; keep up to date on matters affecting the JETSB and keep the JETSB apprised of
such matters; and provide a quarterly status report to the JETSB regarding the overall status of the
911 program. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
V. Maintain a level of familiarity with ICC regulations as they apply to the 911 system.
W. Oversee the implementation and renewal of intergovernmental agreements and other written
documentation as required by the ICC and other regulatory commissions.
X. Be available in an "on call" status in order to provide assistance in any type of emergency, as
needed by the PSAP or at the direction of the chief of police or his designee. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
Y. Work with the JETSB's legal counsel on legal matters, as directed by the JETSB. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-
2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 31/460
Z. Provide expertise, recommendations and assistance for the efficient operation and maintenance of
the entire 911 system.
AA. Work with the various PSAP personnel to efficiently maintain, update and upgrade the 911 CAD
(computer aided dispatch) systems.
BB. Coordinate the testing of 911 lockboxes on an annual basis and assist in training users and
dispatchers in their use.
CC. Maintain and distribute a list of lockbox contact persons to all PSAPs. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
DD. Perform a periodic review to determine if agencies serving as a PSAP remain in compliance with
the criteria and standards of operating as established by the city's JETSB. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012;
amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
EE. Provide PSAP administrators with the opportunity to obtain current 911 training opportunities.
FF. Work with the communications supervisor and the chief of police during the transition and move to
the new police department (estimated 2012). (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
GG. Coordinate and/or conduct training for PSAP personnel in the utilization and operation of JETSB
and 911 equipment.
HH. Maintain the JETSB standard operating procedures (SOPs) manual.
II. Draft SOPs and policies for review by the communications supervisor and the chief of police prior to
being submitted to the city's JETSB for approval. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012; amd. Ord. 3271, 8-10-
2015)
JJ. Be available for emergency part time dispatch fill in when unable to fill in with regular or other part
time dispatchers.
KK. Oversee the transition in the next generation 911. (The next generation 911 [abbreviated NG-911]
refers to an initiative aimed at updating the 911 service infrastructure in the United States and
Canada in order to improve public emergency communications services in a wireless mobile
society. In addition to calling 911 from a phone, it intends to enable the public to be able to transmit
text, images, video and data to the 911 center [the public safety answering point or "PSAP"]. The
initiative also envisions additional types of emergency communications and data transfer. This NG-
911 infrastructure is intended to replace the current services over time. The national emergency
number association, or "NENA", first identified the need for NG-911 in 2000 and started
development actions in 2003 and has developed the full definition and standards for NG-911.)
(Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 32/460
1-8F-4: COMPENSATION:
The 911 coordinator shall receive such compensation and benefits as the mayor and city council shall
fix from time to time. (Ord. 3030, 1-9-2012)
Chapter 9
ETHICS
1-9-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The regulations of section 5-151 and article 102 of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5
Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this chapter), are
hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the city to the
extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5. (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5
Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c). (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-3: INTERPRETATION:
This chapter does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which
regulate the conduct of city officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or
policies are less restrictive than this chapter, however, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail in
accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a). (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Gifts:
1. The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act by an
officer or any employee of the city is hereby prohibited.
2. The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the
city under the act is hereby prohibited.
B. Political Activities: The participation in political activities prohibited under the act by any officer or
employee of the city is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-5: PENALTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 33/460
The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of the act. (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-6: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date hereof shall be incorporated
into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and
making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its
provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this chapter by
reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the city. (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
1-9-7: UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OF PROVISIONS:
A. If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this chapter shall be
repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to
any further appeals or rehearings. This chapter shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the city council if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
B. If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality
of the remainder of the act or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the
act as adopted by this chapter shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this
chapter relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without
further action by the city council. (Ord. 1948, 5-3-2004)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLAN COMMISSION
2-1-1: CREATED:
A city plan commission is hereby created. (2013 Code)
2-1-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The plan commission shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council. Each member shall serve a term of two (2) years or until a
successor is appointed. The city administrator shall be an ex officio member of the commission. (2013
Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 34/460
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION:
A. Chair: The mayor shall designate a member of the plan commission to serve as chair.
B. Rules Of Procedure: The commission shall establish and adopt rules of procedure for the conduct
of the business thereof. (2013 Code)
2-1-4: GENERAL POWERS:
A. Official Comprehensive Plan:
1. The plan commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council a comprehensive plan for
the present and future development or redevelopment of the city.
2. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of
which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the city.
3. The plan may include reasonable requirements with reference to streets, alleys, public grounds
and other improvements.
4. Such plan may be implemented by ordinances:
a. Establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and of areas subject to
redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein defined.
b. Establish reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of
public streets, ways for public service facilities, school grounds, size of lots to be used for
residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and
sewage collection and treatment.
5. The plan commission shall recommend changes from time to time in the official comprehensive
plan.
B. Improvements: The plan commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council from time to
time plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan.
C. Other Powers: The plan commission shall exercise such powers as may be conferred by the city
council. (2013 Code)

Chapter 3
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
APPOINTMENT COMMITTEE: Shall consist of the mayor, the commissioner of public health and
safety, the merit board, the human resources and risk management director and the chief of the
appropriate department.
BOARD: The board of fire and police commissioners of the city of Marion.
FIREFIGHTER: Any person holding a position in the Marion fire department, except as modified in this
chapter.
OFFICER: Any sworn officer holding a position in the Marion police department, except as modified in
this chapter. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
2-3-2: BOARD CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
There is hereby created, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1 and article VII, section 6 of
the Illinois constitution, a board of fire and police commissioners which shall consist of three (3)
members who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval and consent of a majority of the city
council. The term of office shall be three (3) years, and members shall serve until their successors are
appointed and have qualified. No appointments shall be made by any mayor within thirty (30) days of
the expiration of his/her term of office. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-3: MEMBERSHIP RESTRICTIONS; REMOVALS:
No person holding an office in the city shall be a member of the board. The acceptance of any such
office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his/her position as a member of
the board. Members are subject to removal for cause by a majority vote of the city council. (Ord. 1925,
10-6-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 36/460
2-3-4: AUTHORITY:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the duty and authority to compile the register of
eligible names resulting from the examination process for original appointment in the classified
services of the fire and police departments; the promotional eligibility register for promotional
appointments; and shall serve as the body to hear appeals from any suspension, demotion or
termination which may be imposed by the city against any police officer or firefighter, and to hear
appeals as a result of complaints brought against a member of the police or fire department by a
member of the public. The board shall have the authority to discipline or discharge police officers or
firefighters. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-5: MEETINGS:
A. Notice; Closed Sessions: Notice of regular or special meetings shall be posted in accordance with
the open meetings act and open to the public. During any regular or special meeting, a closed
session may be held upon a proper motion made by a member of the board. Closed sessions may
be limited to board members and such invited persons as the board may deem necessary.
B. Quorum: Two (2) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of all business.
C. Chairperson And Vice Chairperson: The board shall elect a chairperson to serve during the fiscal
year. The chairperson shall serve for one year or until a successor is duly elected and qualified.
The board may designate one member to serve as vice chairperson. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-6: OFFICERS AND ADVISERS:
A. Secretary: The board shall elect a member as secretary to keep the minutes of the board's
proceedings and who shall be custodian of all records pertaining to the business of the board and
who shall keep a record of all examinations held.
B. Attorney For Board: The city attorney shall represent the board and handle all matters before the
board upon behalf of the city. In the event that the city attorney shall represent the board, the city
may employ an attorney of its choosing to serve as prosecutor before the board. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-
2003)
2-3-7: GOVERNING RULES:
A. Formulate And Distribute: The board shall formulate rules to carry out the purposes of these
provisions. All rules and revisions thereto shall be made available for distribution but not more than
ten (10) days from the date of adoption.
B. Substance And Application: The governing rules shall apply only to the examination process for
certification to the eligibility list and promotional register and to the appeals process which may be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 37/460
filed by an officer or firefighter as a result of a suspension, demotion or termination imposed by the
city.
C. Limitation Of Rules: No governing rules of the board shall apply to the operation of the police or fire
department or the conduct of each department's members.
D. Examination Process: The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the authority to
promulgate rules governing the examination process for original appointment and promotion in the
classified service of the fire and police departments. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-8: PROCEDURES FOR APPOINTMENT, PROMOTION AND REMOVAL OF
POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL:
A. Application Process:
1. Application Forms: Application forms for positions in the police or fire department shall be
available in the city clerk's office. Completed forms shall be kept on file pending publication of
the test date. Upon publication of the test date, the clerk shall notify, by mail, those persons who
have completed an application form that said form will be available in the clerk's office during
regular business hours. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
2. Time For Filing; Preemployment Agreement: Applications for positions in the police or fire
department shall consist of a completed application form provided by the city. Applications shall
be submitted to the city clerk's office by the deadline determined by the board with respect to
each examination. Such dates shall be included in the publication of the examination notice. In
addition, each person submitting an application shall submit a signed preemployment agreement
on the form provided by the city clerk.
3. Informational Booklet: Upon submission of a completed application form and the signed
preemployment agreement, each applicant shall receive a written explanation of the testing
procedures for original appointment to the police or fire department. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
B. Appointments: The board, upon compilation of an eligibility list for original appointment to either the
fire department or police department, shall deliver to the mayor an alphabetical list of names of all
qualified and eligible persons for the positions. The mayor, in conjunction with the appointment
committee, shall make all appointments to the fire and police departments from the list of eligible
candidates, or the mayor, in conjunction with the appointment committee, may appoint a former
employee of the fire or police department who was in the employment of the city within the
immediate preceding three (3) years. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. Ord. 2028, 8-1-2005)
C. Promotions:
1. The board, upon completion of an eligibility register for promotional appointments to either the
police department or fire department, shall deliver to the appointment committee an alphabetical
list of the names of all qualified and eligible people for said positions. The appointment
committee shall make all promotional appointments to the police and fire departments from the
list of eligible candidates. Any certificate of appointment issued to any officer or member of the
police or fire department shall be signed by the mayor. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 38/460
2. If a candidate does not wish to be certified as one of the eligible candidates for promotion, then
his name will be dropped from the eligibility list, or if the certified letter is returned from the post
office as undeliverable, then the board of police and fire commissioners will remove the name of
the unavailable candidate from the eligibility list. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
D. Review Of Disciplinary Action:
1. Appeals Board: The board has no authority in disciplinary matters involving police officers and
firefighters other than to serve as an appeal board from any disciplinary action taken by the chief
of that department.
2. Criteria For Appeal: Any police officer or firefighter who has been suspended, demoted or
terminated by action of a chief may appeal that action to the board.
3. Decision: The board is hereby granted the authority to affirm, modify, or reverse the decision by
the chief. The chief may appeal any decision of the board to reverse his decision to the circuit
court pursuant to the administrative review law.
4. Application Of Disciplinary Action: The provisions of this subsection shall apply only to full time
firefighters and full time police officers who hold the rank of patrol officer or firefighter or above
and not to any other personnel of the city or the police or fire chief. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-9: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall provide to the mayor an annual report of its activities and of the rules in force and the
practical effect thereof. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-10: FACILITIES AND FUNDS:
The city shall allow reasonable use of public buildings for meetings and for the holding of
examinations and shall provide adequate funds in the annual appropriation for the operation of the
board. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)

FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED:
There shall be established in the city a board known as the foreign fire insurance tax board. (Ord.
2291, 11-23-2009)
2-4-2: COMPOSITION; ELECTION:
The seven (7) member foreign fire insurance tax board shall be elected in whole by the city fire
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 39/460
department and shall consist of the fire chief, who shall hold office by virtue of rank, and six (6)

Chapter 5
JOINT EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEMS BOARD
2-5-1: ESTABLISHED:
A. As authorized by 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750 et seq. (hereinafter the act), the county of
Williamson, state of Illinois, a unit of local government (hereinafter the county) and the city of
Herrin, state of Illinois, a municipal corporation (hereinafter Herrin), did on November 22, 1993,
enter into an intergovernmental agreement establishing a joint emergency telephone systems
board (hereinafter the board).
B. The city of Marion (hereinafter Marion), did on April 4, 1994, establish its own emergency telephone
system board.
C. The act has been amended from time to time by the Illinois legislature requiring changes in the
process and appointment of board members and other matters. Most recently, pursuant to public
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 40/460
act 99-6, the legislature created a mandatory requirement of only one joint board for Williamson
County.
D. The county, Herrin, and Marion must comply with the law and join together to form only one
emergency telephone systems board for Williamson County.
E. The corporate authorities, being the county, Herrin, and Marion, shall provide pursuant to the act for
the manner and number of appointees to the board, as long as there are at least five (5) members
appointed to the board, and one member shall be a member of the county board of Williamson
County, one member shall be a public member who is a resident of the local exchange service
territory included in the 9-1-1 coverage area, and the other members shall be representatives of 9-
1-1 public safety agencies (as defined by the act) within the 9-1-1 coverage area and who
participate in emergency 9-1-1 services, including, but not limited to, police departments, fire
departments, emergency medical services providers, and emergency services and disaster
agencies, and appointed on the basis of their ability or experience.
F. The corporate authorities being the county, Herrin, and Marion, shall determine the powers and
duties of the board, pursuant to the act, and this joint agreement shall define such powers and
duties.
G. Illinois Statutes1 require auditing of governmental entities which expend public funds and the
concept of transparency of government being of extreme importance. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-2: COMPOSITION:
A. The board will be comprised of nine (9) members.
1. Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by Herrin pursuant to its rules. Two (2)
members shall be from public safety agencies (as defined by the act) within Herrin who
participate in emergency 9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience. One member
shall be a public member who is a resident of the local exchange service territory as required by
the act. If at any time one of Herrin's members resigns from the board during their term, Herrin
shall appoint a new representative, based on ability and experience, within Herrin, to complete
the remainder of that term. If the public member resigns, that member shall be replaced with a
public member, and if a representative from the public safety agency resigns, that member shall
be replaced by another representative from a public safety agency. Consideration shall first be
given to a member of the Herrin public safety answering point (PSAP) agency.
2. Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by the county pursuant to its rules. Two (2)
members shall be from public safety agencies (as defined by the act) within Williamson County
who participate in emergency 9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience, and the
remaining member shall be a county commissioner. If at any time one of the county members
resigns from the board during their term, the county shall appoint a new member based on ability
and experience to complete the remainder of the term. If a commissioner resigns, that member
shall be replaced with another commissioner, and if a representative from a public safety agency
resigns, that member shall be replaced by another representative from a public safety agency.
Consideration shall first be given to a member of the county public safety answering point
(PSAP) agency.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 41/460
3. Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by Marion pursuant to its rules. Two (2)
members shall be from public safety agencies (as defined by the act) within Marion who
participate in emergency 9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience, and the
remaining member may be either a city commissioner or another member of a public safety
agency. If at any time one of Marion's members resigns from the board during their term, Marion
shall appoint a new representative, based on ability and experience, to complete the remainder
of the term. If a commissioner resigns, that member shall be replaced with another
commissioner, and if a representative from a public safety agency resigns, that member shall be
replaced by another representative from a public safety agency. Consideration shall first be
given to a member of the Marion public safety answering point (PSAP) agency.

participates in emergency 9-1-1 services, terminates their employment with the public safety
agency, their appointment to the board will also be terminated effective the same date of
termination from employment with the public safety agency. The corporate authority who originally
appointed that member to the board shall appoint a new member from a public safety agency (as
defined by the act) within the 9-1-1 coverage area who participates in emergency 9-1-1 services to
serve the remainder of the term. If that member was appointed from a PSAP, then another person
from the PSAP shall be appointed to serve the remainder of the term. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-3: COMPENSATION:
Members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for their actual and
necessary expenses. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-4: TERMS OF OFFICE:
All members appointed to serve on the board shall serve three (3) year staggered terms pursuant to
the act, with one-third (1/3) of the members' terms set to expire January 1, 2016, one-third (1/3) set to
expire January 1, 2017, and remaining board members' terms to expire January 1, 2018. Members
may be reappointed at the expiration of their term. All reappointments or new appointments made
thereafter will be for three (3) years from the date of expiration of the previous term. The one-third (1/3)
shall be determined as one member from each corporate authority. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The powers and duties of the board shall be in accord with those set out in 50 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 750/15.4 as current and as amended in the future.
B. The board may create bylaws, which will become effective upon approval of a majority vote of the
board, and a copy of which shall be submitted to the Williamson County board of commissioners,
the Herrin city council, and the Marion city council.
C. The county, Herrin, and Marion being required by law to submit annual audits for any governmental
entity spending funds of those governments and being responsible for establishing the powers and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 42/460
duties of the board and in the interest of transparency in government, require that the board
conduct an annual audit as set forth in 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 310 et seq.
D. Any and all funds collected for the 9-1-1 system shall be kept in the 9-1-1 fund, which is overseen
by the county treasurer. The board treasurer shall work with the county treasurer and 9-1-1
coordinator on investment of JETSB funds and payments of all 9-1-1 bills. All 9-1-1 funds currently
in the possession of the city of Marion are to be combined into the fund with county and Herrin 9-1-
1 funds pursuant to the joining of two (2) former boards into one joint board.
E. The sheriff, the Herrin police chief, and the Marion police chief will continue to operate and staff
their 9-1-1 dispatch PSAP centers.
F. Pursuant to 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/40(b) and beginning October 1, 2016, and every
October 1 thereafter, the board shall report to the department of state police audited financial
statements showing total revenue and expenditures for the previous fiscal year. The statements
shall include a detailed summary of revenue from all sources, operating expenses, capital
expenditures, cash balances, and any other financial information deemed relevant by the
department of state police. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
Chapter 6
CULTURAL AND CIVIC CENTER BOARD
2-6-1: CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is created the Marion cultural and civic center board, hereinafter referred to as the "board",
which shall have the duty of administering the operation and maintenance of the building and facility
known and referenced as the "Marion Cultural And Civic Center". The primary purpose of the board is
to encourage and promote a continuing program for the development and propagation of the arts and
of cultural and civic activities that will inure to the benefit of all the citizens of the city. (1977 Code
§§ 2.44.010, 2.44.020; amd. 2013 Code)
2-6-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS; REMOVALS:
The board shall consist of thirteen (13) members, twelve (12) to be appointed by the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council. The twelve (12) members first appointed to the board by the
mayor and council shall be appointed to serve terms as follows: four (4) for a term of three (3) years,
four (4) for a term of two (2) years and four (4) for a term of one year. All subsequent appointments by
the mayor and council shall be for a term of three (3) years, except in the event of a vacancy, in which
case, an appointment shall be for the time remaining in the unexpired term in which the vacancy
occurs. The thirteenth member shall be a senior at Marion High School appointed annually to a term
of one year by the high school faculty. Any member may be removed from the board upon threefourths
(3/4) of the city council voting for such removal. (1977 Code § 2.44.030)
2-6-3: ORGANIZATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 43/460
A. Bylaws And Rules; Quorum: The board shall adopt bylaws and such rules as may be deemed
necessary to conduct the affairs of the board and the operation of the center in an orderly manner;
provided, that a quorum shall not be less than a majority of the members appointed to the board.
(1977 Code § 2.44.080)
B. Officers: The officers of the board shall consist of a chair, vice chair, secretary and treasurer. Each
of the officers shall be elected annually by the members of the board except the chair, who shall be
appointed by the mayor annually, with the advice and consent of the city council. (1977 Code
§ 2.44.040)
C. Meetings: The board shall meet regularly on a designated day each month, and more often as the
occasion requires at the call of the chair. Such meetings shall be held in the civic center building.
(1977 Code § 2.44.050)
2-6-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board is empowered and authorized to manage and administer the center in keeping with and for
the purposes set forth in this chapter; to maintain the center building and equipment in a state of good
repair; to conduct the operation of the center on sound economic principles consistent with the primary
purpose for its establishment; and to employ such personnel as may be reasonably necessary to
accomplish those things the board is authorized and empowered to do. (1977 Code § 2.44.060)
2-6-5: BUDGET AND ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall prepare and present to the city council an annual budget on or before the first Monday
in April and shall, at the same time, present to the city council a report of the activities and
presentations conducted at the center during the preceding year. (1977 Code § 2.44.070; amd. 2013
Code)

There is created the Marion senior citizens' council, referred to in this chapter as the "council", the
primary purpose of which is to encourage and promote a continuing program for the development and
propagation of activities, programs and projects at the Marion Senior Citizens' Center that will inure to

2-7-5: BUDGET AND ANNUAL REPORT:
The council shall prepare and present to the city council an annual budget on or before the first

Title 3
FINANCE AND TAXATION
Chapter 1
GENERAL FINANCE PROVISIONS
3-1-1: FISCAL AND MUNICIPAL YEARS:
The fiscal year and the municipal year for the city shall hereafter commence on May 1 of each year
and end on April 30 of each succeeding year. (1977 Code § 1.16.010)
3-1-2: SIGNATURES ON CHECKS:
All checks for payment of money by the city shall be signed by one of the authorized city
commissioners and either the city treasurer or the assistant city treasurer. (Ord. 3366, 2-3-2017)
3-1-3: ANNUAL AUDIT:
An annual audit of all city funds shall be conducted by an independent state licensed auditor as soon
as practicable after April 30. (2013 Code)
3-1-4: ACCEPTANCE OF OFFERED FUNDS:
In the unlikely event that any funds should be offered or made available to the city without affecting
the city's credit and without the city incurring any liability or obligation whatsoever, the mayor and no
less than two (2) of the city commissioners are hereby authorized to do those things and to perform
such lawful acts as may be necessary to accept and receive such funds on behalf of the city. (Ord.
1241, 7-11-1988)
3-1-5: CASH RESERVE BALANCE POLICY:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this section is to establish a cash reserve balance policy tailored to the
needs of the city to ensure against unforeseen events that would adversely affect the financial
condition of the city and jeopardize the continuation of necessary public services. This section will
ensure the city maintains an adequate cash reserve balance in the city's general fund to provide
the ability to:
1. Provide sufficient cash flow for daily financial needs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 46/460
2. Support the highest possible bond rating.
3. Offset significant economic downturns or revenue shortfalls.
4. Provide funds for unforeseen emergency expenditures.
B. Definition: Cash reserve balance is the term that will be used to represent the general fund cash set
aside from operating funds to be used for the purposes as described in subsection A of this
section.
C. General Policy:
1. The cash reserve balance for the general fund shall be maintained at a minimum level equal to
or greater than twenty five percent (25%) of the general fund current year budgeted
expenditures including transfers from the general fund less capital outlays supported by specific
revenue sources.
2. The cash reserve balance shall be reviewed annually during the budget process.
3. If at any time during or after the budget process, the city council determines that a portion of the
twenty five percent (25%) reserve must be used, the city council will take all necessary actions
to increase the cash reserve balance to the twenty five percent (25%) threshold in future years.
(Ord. 3004, 10-10-2011)
Chapter 2
BUDGET OFFICER FINANCE SYSTEM
3-2-1: BUDGET OFFICER:
A. Position Created And Designated; Term: There is created hereby the position of budget officer in
the city, who shall be designated by the commissioner of accounts and finances, with a two-thirds
(2/3) vote of the city council. The budget officer shall serve at the pleasure of the city council.
B. Oath And Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the budget officer shall take oath and
post bond as provided by statute.
C. May Hold Another Office: The budget officer may hold another municipal office, either elected or
appointed.
D. Compensation: The budget officer shall not receive compensation for this office.
E. Powers And Duties: The budget officer shall have the following powers and duties:
1. To permit, encourage, and establish the efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting,
accounting, and other fiscal management procedures in all municipal departments,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 47/460
commissions, and boards.
2. To compile an annual budget in accord with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.3.
3. To examine all books and records of all city departments, commissions, and boards which relate
to monies received and paid out by the city, its departments, commissions, and boards, and
debts and accounts receivable, amounts owed by or to the city and its departments,
commissions, and boards.
4. To obtain such additional information from the city and its departments, commissions, and
boards as may be useful for purposes of compiling a municipal budget; such information to be
furnished by the city and its departments, commissions, and boards, in the form required by the
budget officer. Any department, commission, or board which refuses to make such information
as requested to the budget officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any
subsequent budget for the city until such department, commission, or board shall comply in full
with the request of the budget officer.
5. To establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no expenditures are made by
the city or its departments, commissions, or boards except as authorized by the budget. (Ord.
2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-2: COMPILATION AND CONTENTS OF BUDGET:
The budget officer shall compile a budget which contains estimates of revenues available to the city
for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the city
and all of its departments, commissions, and boards. Revenue estimates and expenditure
recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management
practices. The budget shall be itemized in a manner to conform with the chart of accounts utilized by
the city's accounting system. The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures
for the two (2) years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. Each
budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made. (Ord.
2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-3: PASSAGE OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
A. Passage of the annual budget by adoption of an appropriate ordinance by the corporate authorities
shall be in lieu of passage of the appropriation ordinance as required by statute.
B. The annual budget shall be published in the manner provided in section 3-2-7 of this chapter.
C. The annual budget shall be adopted by the corporate authorities before the beginning of the fiscal
year to which it applies. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-4: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT, REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT FUND:
A. In the preparation of the budget by the budget officer, an amount not to exceed three percent (3%)
of the equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by the city may be accumulated in
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 48/460
a separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs, and/or
replacement of specific types of municipal equipment or other tangible property, both real and
personal, to be designated as the "capital improvement, repair or replacement fund".
B. Expenditures from the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund shall be budgeted in the
fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur.
C. Upon the completion or abandonment of any project, or in the event any surplus monies remain
after the completion or abandonment of any project for which the capital improvement, repair or
replacement fund was instituted, then such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement,
repair or replacement shall be transferred to the general corporate fund of the city on the first day
of the fiscal year following such abandonment or completion, or discovery of surplus funds. (Ord.
2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-5: REVISIONS TO BUDGET:
Heads of city departments and boards may, with prior approval of the budget officer and the city
administrator, initiate transfers of funds between line items within departments and may delete, add or
change line items within departments. Nothing herein shall prohibit any commissioner to initiate
transfers of funds between line items within his or her department and may delete, add or change line
items within his or her department. All other revisions by transfer, deletion or adding or changing
budgeted items require approval by the city council by a two-thirds (2/3) vote. However, under no
circumstances shall a revision be made to the budget which increases the budget in the event funds
are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision. Nothing in this section shall prohibit revision
in the event funds are available from any source including, but not limited to, loan proceeds, grant
funding, anticipated tax receipts or projected sales tax revenue. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-6: FUNDS FOR CONTINGENCY PURPOSES:
The annual budget may contain money set aside for contingency purposes not to exceed ten percent
(10%) of the total budget, which may be expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the city
council. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-7: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE AND HEARING ON BUDGET:
A. The city council shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently available to public inspection
for at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget by publication in the journal of
the proceedings of the corporate authorities or in such other form as the city council may prescribe.
B. Not less than one week after the publication of the tentative annual budget and prior to final action
on the budget, the city council shall hold at least one public hearing on the tentative annual budget,
after which hearing or hearings the tentative annual budget may be further revised and passed
without any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be given by publication
in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least one week prior to the time of the
hearing. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 49/460
Chapter 3
DEBT MANAGEMENT POLICY
3-3-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish guidelines for the issuance of debt, including leases,
financing of capital projects, infrastructure and other projects deemed necessary by the city council.
This policy will assist the city council to:
A. Obtain financing only when necessary.
B. Reduce debt interest costs.
C. Take all practical precautions to avoid any financial decisions which will negatively impact current
credit ratings on future debt issues.
D. Secure and maintain the highest possible bond rating. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-2: ANNUAL REVIEW:
During the preparation of the city's annual budget, the city council shall perform the following tasks in
relation to its debt:
A. Assess the benefits for financing of projects budgeted in the next budget year.
B. Review outstanding debt for refunding (interest savings, eliminating restrictive covenants, etc.)
and/or consolidation.
C. Review compliance with applicable financing documents (including bond ordinances, credit
enhancement policies, continuing disclosure requirements, etc.). (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-3: PERIODIC REVIEWS:
The city council or its designee, semiannually, shall review debt service accounts to ensure they are
maintained in accordance with their bond ordinances. As conditions merit, the city council or its
designee shall review or identify outstanding debt issues for refunding for interest savings. (Ord. 3005,
10-10-2011)
3-3-4: DEBT LIMITS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 50/460
As a home rule unit of government, the city is not subject to debt limits. It has the ability to issue
general obligation debt without limitation or referendum. However, it is the intent of the city council to
be prudent in its issuance of debt. Debt repaid solely from collection of property taxes should not
exceed ten percent (10%) of the city's most recent equalized assessed valuation. However, this does
not apply to general obligation bonds issued by the city that it intends to repay from sources other than
property taxes. If less than one hundred percent (100%) of the annual debt service associated with
any bond is to be paid from property taxes, the amount of property taxes extended shall be discounted
at the bond interest rate(s) to determine the bond par amount to be considered general obligation debt
for purposes of its self-imposed debt limit (this calculation is not required if the bond's principal
amounts are identified and the corresponding debt service is equal to the property tax levied). Debt
intended to be repaid from sources other than property taxes are excluded from this section, whether
or not it is issued as general obligation debt. On an annual basis, prior to abating the current property
tax levy associated with such general obligation bonds, the city council shall identify and designate the
funds to be used for the payment of such bonds. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-5: DEBT FEATURES AND STRUCTURES:
Debt may be issued on the basis of: a) fixed or variable rate; b) taxable or tax exempt; c) rated or
nonrated; d) bank qualified or nonbank qualified; e) credit enhanced or noncredit enhanced; f) term or
serial maturities, including balloon payments; g) callable and noncallable; h) private placements; and i)
restrictive covenants as required. Credit enhancement and ratings should be used where applicable
and there is cost benefit based on interest rate savings. Long term debt should be callable with the
earliest possible call feature that does not impact the overall interest rate. The recommended
maximum call feature is a ten (10) year par call. Variable rate debt should be considered when interest
rates are expected to decline or remain flat. When possible, debt should be issued as bank qualified.
This section is not all encompassing and is not intended to limit the city's debt structures. (Ord. 3005,
10-10-2011)
3-3-6: SHORT TERM DEBT:
For purposes of this policy, "short term debt" is defined as any debt incurred whose final maturity is
five (5) years or less. Short term debt may be used to purchase equipment and for other purposes
deemed necessary by the city council, including the refunding of debt, as long as the purpose is not
prohibited by state statute. Short term debt issued for operating/cash flow purposes should mature
within the time frame in which the proceeds will be spent, but no longer than one year after such time.
(Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-7: LONG TERM DEBT:
For purposes of this policy, "long term debt" is defined as any debt incurred whose final maturity is
greater than five (5) years. Long term debt may be used for the purchase of equipment, capital
projects and/or any other purpose deemed necessary by the city council (other than for operating
purposes), including refunding of debt, as long as the purpose is not prohibited by state statute.
Financing terms shall not exceed the useful life of the projects financed. Debt issues should not
exceed forty (40) years. When issuing long term debt, the city council should consider the following
debt types:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 51/460
A. Alternate revenue debt obligations or general obligations debt to be repaid from sources other than
property taxes. These obligations require the expected revenues to sufficiently meet debt service
requirements for the life of these obligations.
B. General revenue debt obligations to be repaid from property taxes. This obligation is payable from
a direct property tax levied and collected within the city.
C. Private activity obligations. These obligations may be issued by the city for the behalf of the issuer
that provide special financing benefits to qualified projects. These obligations are subject to
internal revenue service requirements and state volume caps to preserve tax exemption. The cost
of issuance of private activity obligations is usually higher than for governmental purpose
obligations. Typically, the city has no obligation to pay debt service for private activity obligations;
they are not a liability of the city and do not count as city debt. They should be used to promote
economic development within the city.
D. Special service area and special assessment obligations. These obligations may be issued by the
city for the designated taxpayers receiving the benefit. The taxpayers within the designated area
are responsible for the payment of debt service on such obligations and can be paid from property
taxes or a special assessment within the designated area. These obligations are typically issued in
response to property owners within the designated area requesting infrastructure/utilities
improvements. These obligations are not a liability of the city and are not considered city debt.
Alternate revenue debt obligations or general obligations debt are to be repaid from sources other
than property taxes. These obligations require the expected revenues to sufficiently meet debt
service requirements for the life of these obligations.
E. Tax increment financing obligations. These obligations are used to promote economic development
within a designated tax increment finance district. They are repaid from the incremental property
taxes generated within the district. Unless backed by the city, such obligations are not a liability of
the city and are not considered a city debt. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-8: FINANCIAL PROFESSIONAL:
When deemed necessary by the city council, it shall seek advice from a financial professional. The
financial professional to be used by the city should have experience with debt structuring (including
type and length) and working with bond rating services and other services deemed necessary by the
city council. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-9: CAPITAL LEASING:
Capital leasing, when offered, is an option to finance the acquisition of major depreciable assets. A
capital lease is a long term lease that transfers to the lessee most rights and obligations concerning
the asset leased, and usually transfers ownership at the end of the lease. The city council should
consider the advice of the city's finance professional or bond counsel when capital leasing
arrangements are used and when federal tax forms are prepared to ensure that all federal tax laws
are followed. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 52/460
3-3-10: INVESTMENT OF BOND PROCEEDS:
A. The investment of bond proceeds shall be dictated by the bond indenture, state statutes and the
city's investment policy. The city finance director-treasurer, with the advice of the city's financial
professional, shall prepare the drawdown requirements for the bond proceeds which shall be used
to create investment parameters for the bond proceeds. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Due consideration shall be given debt covenants and arbitrage requirements, the purpose of which
is to maintain compliance with both. Investment adjustments shall be made as required.
C. Debt service reserve funds shall be maintained and invested, as applicable, in compliance with the
above. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-11: MODIFICATIONS OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter is not meant as all encompassing but rather a guideline, subject to periodic (or at least
annual) review by the city council, at which time it may be modified and amended as the city council
deems appropriate. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
Chapter 4
PURCHASING REQUIREMENTS
3-4-1: PURCHASING PROCEDURES:
A. Purchase Orders: All purchases require the completion, submittal, and approval of a purchase
order. Purchase orders shall be completed in accordance with this chapter.
B. Departmental Purchasing Agent(s): Each department head and superintendent is hereby
designated as departmental purchasing agent. Each department head or superintendent may, at
his discretion, appoint supervisory employee(s) as departmental purchasing agent(s) who shall be
responsible for ensuring completion and submission of the required purchase order and supporting
documentation. The departmental purchasing agent shall be responsible for purchasing activities
in the absence of the department head/superintendent. The department head shall be responsible
for ensuring the proper purchasing procedures are followed, that sufficient funds are budgeted for
any and all purchases, and that required documentation is kept in the department's files.
C. Responsibilities Of City Administrator/City Council: The city administrator shall have the authority to
reject any purchase order that has not been completed according to the stated procedures, or
return to the department any purchase order that requires additional attention. The city
administrator shall provide guidance to departments on purchasing procedures and guidelines.
Any questions or instances not addressed by this procedure shall be referred to the city
administrator for determination on whether to refer to the city council for consideration or
amendment of the policy.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 53/460
D. Application Of State Or Federal Law: Any state or federal law that is more restrictive than this
procedure shall supersede the affected portion of this procedure. (Ord. 2332, 10-11-2010)
3-4-2: PURCHASING GUIDELINES:
The following guidelines shall apply to purchases of items that have been approved, either generally
or specifically, in the budget:
A. Purchases of less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); department head approval (all
departments): Purchases in this category may be made by the departmental purchasing agent.
Such purchases do not require competitive quotes. However, the departmental purchasing agent
should ensure, when possible, that such items are acquired at the lowest possible price,
considering all relevant factors.
B. Purchases between one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and five thousand dollars ($5,000.00);
commissioner/city administrator approval (nonmajor departments): Nonmajor departments are all
departments other than water, sewer, street, fire, police and library. The water office, however, is
considered a nonmajor department. Purchases in this category may be made by the department
purchasing agent and approved by the department commissioner or city administrator in
department commissioner's absence. It is recommended but not required that three (3) bids be
obtained. If bids are obtained, they should be documented on the purchase order or on a
document attached to the purchase order.
C. Purchases up to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00); department head approval (major departments
only): Purchases in this category may be made by the departmental purchasing agent. It is
recommended but not required that three (3) bids be obtained. If bids are obtained, they should be
documented on the purchase order or on a document attached to the purchase order.
D. Purchases between three thousand one dollars ($3,001.00) and five thousand dollars ($5,000.00);
commissioner/city administrator approval required (major departments only): Purchases in this
category may be made by the departmental purchasing agent and approved by the department
commissioner or city administrator in the commissioner's absence. It is recommended but not
required that three (3) bids be obtained. If bids are obtained, they should be documented on the
purchase order or on a document attached to the purchase order.
E. Purchases over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); city council approval: Purchases in this category
require approval of the city council. Unless required by state statute, the city council, at its
discretion, will decide if bids should be taken and by what method the bids should be obtained.
(Ord. 2332, 10-11-2010)
F. Cooperative or group purchasing is allowed so long as prequalified lists are current and include
qualified sources to ensure maximum open and free competition. No potential bidders will be
precluded from qualifying during the solicitation period, in order to conform to the applicable federal
procurement regulations. (Ord. 3270, 8-10-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 54/460
3-4-3: EXCEPTIONS AND DEVIATIONS:
The following situations may require deviation from the stated procedures:
A. Emergency situations allowing emergency purchases shall be defined as those in which the
operation of a department/division would be hampered, or when the protection and preservation of
public property or life would not be possible without action requiring an emergency purchase, and
required procedures are not possible. Such purchases, not exceeding five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), may be made by the departmental purchasing agent after department head approval.
The department head shall be responsible for determining the extent of the emergency and the
need for the commissioner, and in his/her absence the city administrator, approval for any
emergency purchases between three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) and five thousand dollars
($5,000.00). Any emergency purchase in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) must be
approved by the commissioner or city administrator in the commissioner's absence and shall have
the responsibility of requiring council action as necessary.
B. The following items may be approved by the departmental purchasing agent even if the amount is
over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00):
1. Utilities.
2. Payments on contracts previously approved by the city council.
3. Bulk fuel purchases.
C. The following items do not require a purchase order:
1. Disbursements made from petty cash funds.
2. Travel vouchers.
3. Gas card purchases. (Ord. 2332, 10-11-2010)
3-4-4: SUBDIVISION OF CONTRACTS PROHIBITED:
No purchase, agreement, or contract for services may be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this
policy. (Ord. 2332, 10-11-2010)
Chapter 5
TAXES
ARTICLE A. MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION TAXES
3-5A-1: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 55/460
A. Tax Imposed; Rate; Exclusions: The Corporate Authorities of the Municipality shall and do hereby
impose a tax upon all persons engaged in the Municipality in the business of selling tangible
personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an
agency of the State of Illinois, at retail in the Municipality at the rate of 1.50 percent on and of the
gross receipts from those sales made in the course of such business. This tax shall only be
imposed at the rate of 1.50 percent as authorized by the Act, which is at the same rate that the
Municipality imposes a Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax under the Home Rule
Municipal Service Occupation Tax Act. Under the Act, this additional tax may not be imposed on
the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold
(other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for immediate
consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and
insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics and otherwise or hereafter
required by applicable law.
B. Collection And Enforcement: The tax imposed by the Municipality under this section and the Act
and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident of the tax shall be collected and
enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue.
C. Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the Municipality to impose a tax
upon the privilege of engaging in any business which under the Constitution of the United States
may not be made the subject of taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to
the contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with the Act as it shall
from time to time be in effect.
D. Effective Date: Pursuant to the Municipality's home rule authority, sections 1-2-4 and 4-5-13 of the
Illinois Municipal Code shall not apply to this section. This section shall become effective
immediately upon its adoption and approval and the tax under subsection A of this section shall be
given effect in the time and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 3674, 3-20-2017)
3-5A-2: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A. Tax Imposed; Rate; Exclusions: The Corporate Authorities of the Municipality shall and do hereby
impose a tax upon all persons engaged in the Municipality in the business of making sales of
service at the rate of 1.50 percent of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred
by such servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as
an incident to a sale of service. This tax shall only be imposed at the rate of 1.50 percent of the
selling price, as authorized by the Act which is at the same rate that the Municipality imposes a
Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax under the Home Rule Municipal Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act. Under the Act this additional tax may not be imposed on the sales of food for
human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic
beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and
prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing
materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics and otherwise or hereafter required by
applicable law.
B. Collection And Enforcement: The tax imposed by the Municipality under this section and the Act
and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident of the tax shall be collected and
enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 56/460
C. Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the Municipality to impose a tax
upon the privilege of engaging in any business which under the Constitution of the United States
may not be made the subject of taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to
the contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with the Act as it shall
from time to time be in effect.
D. Effective Date: Pursuant to the Municipality's home rule authority, sections 1-2-4 and 4-5-13 of the
Illinois Municipal Code shall not apply to this section. This section shall become effective
immediately upon its adoption and approval and the tax under subsection A of this section shall be
given effect in the time and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 3675, 3-20-2017)
3-5A-3: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
A. Tax Imposed; Rate: The Corporate Authorities of the City shall and do hereby impose a tax at the
rate of one percent (1.00%) upon the privilege of using, in the City, any item of tangible personal
property which is purchased at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered at a location
within the corporate limits of the City with an agency of the government of the State of Illinois. The
tax shall only be imposed at the rate of one percent (1.00%) and based on the selling price of such
tangible personal property, as "selling price" is defined in the Use Tax Act1, as authorized by the
Act. (Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001)
B. Collection And Enforcement:
1. The City's population is seventeen thousand one hundred twenty nine (17,129) under the most
recently adjusted figures of or supplementing the 2000 Federal census. Under the Act, in home
rule municipalities with less than two million (2,000,000) inhabitants, the tax shall be collected by
the City imposing the tax from persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes
is given as being in such City. (Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001; amd. 2013 Code)
2. The tax imposed by the City under this section and the Act and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident of the tax shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of
Revenue, to the extent authorized by applicable law, if at all, and otherwise shall be collected
and enforced by the City. The City acknowledges that under present law, the Illinois Department
of Revenue does not collect or enforce this tax.
C. Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the City to impose a tax upon the
privilege of engaging in any business which, under the Constitution of the United States, may not
be made the subject of taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to the
contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with the Act as it shall,
from time to time, be in effect.
D. Effective Date: Pursuant to the City's home rule authority, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-4 and
5/4-5-13 shall not apply to this section. This section shall become effective immediately upon its
adoption and approval, and the tax under subsection A of this section shall be given effect in the
time and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001)
3-5A-4: HOTEL OPERATORS' OCCUPATION TAX:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 57/460
A. Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CITY: The City of Marion, Illinois.
CITY COUNCIL AND CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The City Council of the City of Marion, Illinois.
FINANCE DIRECTOR-TREASURER: The City Finance Director-Treasurer of the City of Marion,
Illinois.
HOTEL: Shall have the meaning in the hotel operator's occupation tax act and shall include,
without limitation, facilities referenced as motels.
OPERATOR: As applicable, the owner/operator of each hotel within the city of Marion and the
person(s) having a right of property operating such hotel under applicable law.
PERMANENT RESIDENT: Any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room or rooms
in a motel or hotel for at least seven (7) consecutive days.
PERSON: Any natural person, trustee, court appointed representative, syndicate, association,
partnership, firm, club, company, corporation, business trust, institution, agency, government
corporation, municipal corporation, district or other political subdivision, contractor, supplier,
vendor, vendee, operator, user or owner, or any officers, agents, employees or other
representative, acting either for himself or for any other person in any capacity, or any other entity
recognized by law as the subject of rights and duties. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011; amd. 2013 Code;
Ord. 3216, 9-8-2014)
B. Tax Imposed; Rate And Restrictions:
1. The corporate authorities of the city hereby impose a tax upon all persons engaged in the city in
the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel, as defined in the hotel operators'
occupation tax act, at a rate of three percent (3%) of the gross rental receipts from such renting,
leasing or letting, excluding, however, from the gross rental receipts, the proceeds of such
renting, leasing or letting to permanent residents of that hotel. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011)
2. Persons subject to the tax imposed pursuant to this section may reimburse themselves for their
tax liability for such tax by separately stating such tax as an additional charge, which charge may
be stated in combination, in a single amount, with state tax imposed under the hotel operators'
occupation tax act. However, the tax shall not be levied and imposed upon any permanent
resident or to a person who works and lives in the same hotel or motel. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011;
amd. Ord. 3216, 9-8-2014)
3. Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the city to impose a tax upon the privilege
of engaging in any business which, under the constitution of the United States, may not be made
the subject of taxation by the state of Illinois. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011)
C. Registration Requirements:
1. Each hotel located within the boundaries of the city shall file a "certificate of registration" within
the office of the finance director-treasurer, whose office is located at Marion City Hall, 1102
Tower Square, Marion, Illinois. Registration forms shall be available to each hotel operator
through the office of the city finance director-treasurer. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 58/460
2. It is the duty of the hotel operator to update the "certificate of registration" form on an annual
basis. The final date for filing and updating this certificate of registration shall be December 15 of
each year, commencing December 15, 2011, following the effective date hereof. Any new
business coming under license to do business as a hotel within the city shall file a certificate of
registration no later than thirty (30) days following the first day of operation as a new hotel
business. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011)
D. Report Required: Each operator shall file an "occupancy tax report" each month following the
effective date hereof. The report shall contain the total dollar gross receipts received from room
occupancy rentals along with the total amount due and payable to the city as required by this
section. Occupancy tax reports shall be available to each hotel operator through the office of the
city finance director-treasurer. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
E. Due Date; Late Payment Penalty: All taxes due the city shall be due and payable to the city on or
before the last day of the month immediately following the month of collection. A one percent (1%)
late penalty will be due and payable to the city should any hotel operator fail to file an occupancy
tax report by the end of each given month, and an additional one percent (1%) each month
thereafter. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011)
F. Remittance Of Taxes; Disposition And Use Of Funds:
1. All taxes due and owing the city under this section shall be made payable by or on behalf of the
operator to the "finance director-treasurer of the city of Marion, Illinois", and shall be due and
payable monthly to the finance director-treasurer on or before the tenth day of each month after
the effective date hereof. The finance director-treasurer shall transfer such funds, by the fifteenth
of the month following collection, into a separate fund established for the city tourism fund. (Ord.
2356, 6-13-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
2. The amounts collected by the city pursuant to this section shall be expended by the city solely to
promote tourism and conventions within the city or otherwise to attract nonresident overnight
visitors to the city.
3. No funds received pursuant to this section shall be used to advertise for or otherwise promote
new competition in the hotel business.
G. Interpretation And Effective Date:
1. This section incorporates chapter 6 of this title concerning the local government taxpayers' bill of
rights act.
2. This section shall be effective immediately upon its adoption, approval and publication in
pamphlet form; provided, that the hotel tax imposed by this section shall not become effective
until the later of: a) June 22, 2011; or b) the date that the Illinois finance authority's qualified
501(c)(3) not for profit revenue bonds (Williamson County events commission project), series
2003, are not outstanding. Pursuant to section 6 (powers of home rule units) of article VII (local
government) of the constitution of the state of Illinois, sections 1-2-4, 8-1-7 and 4-5-13 of the
Illinois municipal code shall not apply to this section. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011)
ARTICLE B. SIMPLIFIED TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 59/460
3-5B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
AMOUNT PAID: The amount charged to the taxpayer's service address in the city regardless of where
such amount is billed or paid.
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois department of revenue.
GROSS CHARGE: The amount paid for the act or privilege of originating or receiving
telecommunications in the city and for all services and equipment provided in connection therewith by
a retailer, valued in money, whether paid in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and
property of every kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost
of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor, or service costs or any other
expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the amount thereof shall be included only as and
when paid. "Gross charges" for private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel
termination point within the city and charges for the portion of the interoffice channels provided within
the city. Charges for that portion of the interoffice channel connecting two (2) or more channel
termination points, one or more of which is located within the jurisdictional boundary of the city, shall
be determined by the retailer by multiplying an amount equal to the total charge for the interoffice
channel by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of channel termination points that are
located within the jurisdictional boundary of the city, and the denominator of which is the total number
of channel termination points connected by the interoffice channel. However, "gross charge" shall not
include any of the following:
A. Any amounts added to a purchaser's bill because of a charge made pursuant to: 1) the tax
imposed by this article; 2) the tax imposed by the telecommunications excise tax act; 3) the tax
imposed by section 4251 of the internal revenue code; 4) 911 surcharges; or 5) charges added
to customers' bills pursuant to the provisions of section 9-221 or 9-222 of the public utilities act,
as amended, or any similar charges added to customers' bills by retailers who are not subject to
rate regulation by the Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax
liabilities or other amounts specified in those provisions of the public utilities act;
B. Charges for a sent collect telecommunication received outside of the city;
