(Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
2. When the identity of the owner or other person legally entitled to an abandoned or derelict
vehicle is not known and has been determined in accordance with the provisions hereof, and in
addition to the notice required in subsection B1 of this section, when the identity of the owner or
other person legally entitled to a vehicle is known, the chief of police, or his designee, shall
cause a prominent notice to be placed on the abandoned motor vehicle stating that the vehicle
has been determined to be abandoned in accordance with the abandoned or derelict vehicle
regulations of the city of Marion and that it will be towed and impounded unless removed within
seven (7) days from the date the notice was posted. The date the notice is posted shall be
endorsed on the notice, along with the name of the officer posting such notice, and the
telephone number of the city police department at which information may be obtained relative to
the notice. The chief of police, or his designee, shall cause the owner or other party in
possession of private property on which the vehicle is located to be informed that the vehicle will
be towed and impounded after seven (7) days, unless such vehicle is located on private property
of the owner of such vehicle or such private property owner notified the city police department of
such abandoned or derelict vehicle. Such private property owner shall have all rights of review
under this article if such private property owner is a person legally entitled to such vehicle.
Notice to the owner or party in possession is informational only and not jurisdictional. (Ord. 1759,
3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008; 2013 Code)
5-8A-7: REVIEW OF DETERMINATION OF ABANDONED OR DERELICT VEHICLE:
When a vehicle has been determined to be an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of
this article, the owner thereof or other person legally entitled thereto shall have the right to have such
determination reviewed in accordance with this section.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 154/460
A. Chief Of Police: Any owner of or other person legally entitled to a vehicle determined to be an
abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this article may, within seven (7) days of the
notification required under subsection 5-8A-6B of this article is mailed or personally delivered, as
the case may be, file a written request with the chief of police that he review such determination,
stating the reason or reasons why such vehicle is not an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the
meaning of this article. Within seven (7) days of such written request, the chief of police shall
review such determination, giving the owner or other person an opportunity to personally be heard
and present whatever information as such owner or other person considers pertinent. After
reviewing such determination, the chief of police shall render a written decision thereon which shall
be promptly mailed, postage prepaid, by certified mail, to such owner or other person, or delivered
personally as stated heretofore.
B. Mayor: If the owner of or other person legally entitled to such vehicle does not agree with the
decision of the chief of police after his review, such owner or other person may, within ten (10)
days after the decision of the chief of police is mailed to such owner or other person, file a written
request with the mayor that the mayor review the original determination and the decision of the
chief of police stating the reason or reasons why such vehicle is not an abandoned or derelict
vehicle within the meaning of this article. Within seven (7) days of such written request, the mayor
shall schedule and conduct a hearing to review such determination and such decision. At such
hearing, the mayor shall consider pertinent information presented by the city police department
and such owner or other person. The mayor may also personally inspect such vehicle. The parties,
personally or through counsel, shall also have the right to cross examine each other's witnesses.
After reviewing such determination and such decision, the mayor shall render a written decision
thereon which shall be promptly mailed, postage prepaid, by certified mail, to such owner or other
person, or delivered personally as stated heretofore. If such owner or such other person has not
been charged with violating this article, the review of the mayor shall be the final determination,
and such vehicle may then be towed and impounded if found to be an abandoned vehicle. If such
owner or such other person has been charged with violating this article, then the right of judicial
determination shall apply as hereinafter provided.
C. Judicial Determination: If the owner of or other person legally entitled to a vehicle determined to be
an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this article does not agree with the decision
of the mayor, and such owner or such other person has been charged with violating this article,
such owner or such person may, within seven (7) days after the decision of the mayor is mailed to
such owner or such other person, file a request with the mayor that the vehicle not be towed or
impounded pending the disposition of such charge. If such request is filed, such vehicle shall not
be towed and impounded until such charge has been disposed of. After such charge is disposed
of, finding such owner or other person guilty, such vehicle shall then be towed and impounded
unless such nuisance has then been abated.
D. Stay Of Towing And Impounding: Pending any review of a determination that a vehicle is an
abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this article, any such vehicle shall not be
towed or impounded except as is permitted for emergency tows. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord.
2182, 1-28-2008; 2013 Code)
5-8A-8: TOWING AND IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES; RECLAMATION AND
DISPOSAL:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 155/460
A. Towing And Impoundment; Records Kept: Subject to review of any determination pursuant hereto
that a vehicle is an abandoned or derelict vehicle with the meaning of this article, such abandoned
and derelict vehicle may be towed and impounded after a waiting period of ten (10) days or more
from the date the notification required pursuant to section 5-8A-6 of this article has been mailed or
delivered, as the case may be. The chief of police, or his designee, shall authorize a towing service
to remove and take possession of the abandoned vehicle. The towing service shall safely keep the
towed vehicle and its contents and maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the
owner or any other person legally entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as
provided in this article. When any vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the city police
department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, year of
manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle
identification number, and license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall
also indicate the date and hour of tow, the location towed from, the location towed to, the reason
for towing, and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. A record search of the vehicle shall also
be made. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008)
B. Reclaiming Vehicles: At any time before a vehicle is sold at public sale or disposed of as provided
in this article, the owner or other person legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle
by presenting to the city police department proof of ownership or proof of the right of possession of
the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner thereof or other person entitled thereto until
and unless such owner or such person has paid all towing and storage fees on account of such
vehicle.
C. Disposal Of Unclaimed Vehicles: Abandoned or derelict vehicles which have been towed or
impounded shall be disposed of in accordance with this subsection.
1. Disposal With Notice:
a. Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle, seven (7) years of age or newer, remains
unclaimed by the registered owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a
period of thirty (30) days after notice has been given by mail or delivered as provided in
subsection 5-8A-6B of this article, the city police department shall cause such vehicle to be
sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be
posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the premises
where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to the sale, the city police
department or the towing service where the vehicle is impounded shall cause a notice of the
time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or other person
known by the city police department or the towing service to be legally entitled to the
possession of such vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to
be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle.
b. Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle more than seven (7) years of age is towed or
impounded, it may be sold as provided above or disposed of as junk only at the discretion of
the chief of police, or his designee.
c. A vehicle classified as an antique (25 years of age or older) may also be sold to any person
desiring to restore same.
2. Disposal Without Notice:
a. When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of
an abandoned or derelict vehicle seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined in
accordance with section 5-8A-6 of this article, the vehicle may be sold as provided in
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 156/460
subsection C1 of this section, but without notice of the time and place of the sale being mailed
to the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
b. Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle is more than seven (7) years of age and is towed
and impounded, it may be sold as provided in subsection C1 of this section or disposed of as
junk only at the discretion of the chief of police, or his designee.
3. Proceeds Of Sale: When a vehicle located within the city is authorized to be towed, impounded
and disposed of as set forth in this article, the proceeds of the public sale or other disposition
after the deduction of towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the city
treasury.
4. Police Reports: When a vehicle in the custody of the city police department is reclaimed by the
registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or
otherwise disposed of as provided in this article, a report of the transaction shall be maintained
by the city police department for a period of one year from the date of sale or disposal. (Ord.
1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-9: EMERGENCY TOWS:
Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, when a vehicle is creating a traffic hazard
because of its position in relation to a highway, its physical appearance is causing the impeding of
traffic, or it otherwise presents a danger to the public health and safety on public or private property,
the chief of police, or his designee, may authorize and direct the immediate towing and impounding of
such vehicle without notice to the owner thereof or other person legally entitled thereto. Immediately
thereafter, the owner or other person legally entitled shall be identified and notified in accordance with
this article. The determination may also be reviewed and the vehicle disposed of in accordance with
this article; provided, that if it is concluded that such vehicle is not an abandoned or derelict vehicle
within the meaning of this article, such vehicle shall be released to the owner thereof or other person
legally entitled thereto upon payment of any charges incurred for towing. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd.
2013 Code)
5-8A-10: NONLIABILITY OF POLICE AND TOWING SERVICE:
Any police officer or towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be held to answer or be
liable for damages in any action brought by the registered owner, former registered owner, or his legal
representative, or any other person legally entitled to the possession of a vehicle when the vehicle
was processed and sold or disposed of as provided in this article. All necessary parties shall have the
full right and authority to enter upon private property for the enforcement of this article when any
vehicle is in the view of the general public. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-11: FEE FOR REMOVAL OF CONTAMINANTS:
Anyone in the business of receiving and storing abandoned or derelict motor vehicles who is required
by government regulations to remove from such vehicles mercury or other contaminants may impose
a service charge of twenty five dollars ($25.00) to cover the costs of complying with such regulations.
The city is not obligated for any cost incurred in such removal. (Ord. 3041, 2-27-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 157/460
5-8A-12: PROVISIONS NONEXCLUSIVE:
The provisions of this article shall be considered in addition to any procedures established otherwise
by law or ordinance for the removal and disposition of abandoned or derelict vehicles. (Ord. 1759, 3-
27-2000)
ARTICLE B. VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS
5-8B-1: MULTIPLE VEHICLES FOR SALE:
The offering of two (2) or more motor vehicles for sale at the same time on private property located
within a residentially zoned area is prohibited. At no time and under no circumstances is the offering
for sale of a derelict vehicle or the sale of vehicle parts permitted in open areas on private property
upon which they are situated unless licensed by the city to permit such sale. For the purpose of this
section, a "For Sale" sign posted upon or adjacent to a motor vehicle constitutes an offering for sale
and is prohibited unless specifically allowed herein. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8B-2: ENCLOSURE OF CERTAIN VEHICLES:
Unless otherwise provided herein, all unregistered, inoperable or derelict motor vehicles shall be kept
in a garage in a residential district. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8B-3: DISMANTLING VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
Unless otherwise provided herein, no motor vehicle which is in a state of major disassembly or
disrepair or which is being stripped or dismantled shall be permitted on any property located within a
residential or a nonresidential district unless the property is licensed for such use. The major repair or
demolition of motor vehicles shall not be permitted in residential areas. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8B-4: PARKING REGULATIONS:
A. Generally: All vehicles parked in a residential district shall be parked on a street, a clearly
delineated driveway or within a garage. At no time shall a motor vehicle be parked, stored or in any
manner placed on the front, side or rear yards or otherwise allowed to create a nuisance to
adjoining property owners by placing the vehicle in areas other than herein provided.
B. Commercial Vehicles:
1. No person shall park, store or house more than one commercial vehicle in a residential district.
2. The commercial vehicle parked, stored or housed within a residential district must be owned by
or assigned to the owner of the premises where the vehicle is situated and must be located on
the owner's lot in the residential district.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 158/460
3. The vehicle must not exceed seven feet (7') in height and shall not be a school bus, tractor,
trailer, dump truck, front loader, crane, tow truck or similar vehicle.
4. The commercial vehicle shall be parked to the side or rear of a building so as to be screened
from view of the public right of way as much as possible.
5. For the purpose of this subsection, a commercial vehicle is a vehicle having been issued a B or
a D license plate by the secretary of state. All other commercial vehicles having greater than a D
license plate shall not be parked, stored, or housed within a residential district. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-
2000)
5-8B-5: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
A. Recreational Vehicles: The provisions of this article shall not be construed to amend or alter any
provisions contained in other ordinances regulating the parking and/or storing of recreational
vehicles.
B. Trailers And Towable Vehicles: All provisions of this article shall apply to trailers and towable
vehicles. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
ARTICLE C. VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES AND REMEDIES
5-8C-1: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, demolish, use or
occupy any structure or equipment regulated by this chapter when such conduct is contrary to or in
conflict with or in violation of any provisions stated herein. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8C-2: PENALTY:
Any person, upon conviction of violating any provisions of this chapter, shall be fined as provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code for each violation. Any city police officer is authorized to issue a citation for
each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served, and each citation shall be
deemed a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. 2013 Code)
5-8C-3: NONCOMPLIANCE WITH ORDER:
In case there is not prompt compliance with any violation order, the chief of police may request the city
council to direct the city attorney to institute an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of
competent jurisdiction to collect the penalties provided in section 5-8C-2 of this article. (Ord. 1759, 3-
27-2000)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 159/460
Chapter 9
HAZARDOUS OPENINGS AND STRUCTURES
5-9-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the word "person" includes, but is not limited to, any individual, group
of individuals, partnership, firm or corporation. (1977 Code § 8.16.010)
5-9-2: PROHIBITIONS:
A. No person shall cause or allow to remain upon any lot or tract of real estate within the city any open
pit, well, basement or other similar opening, nor shall any person cause or allow to remain upon
any lot or tract of real estate any building or other structure which has been partially or
substantially destroyed by fire or otherwise and is either uninhabited or uninhabitable unless it is
sealed in such a manner or kept in such condition as to prevent it from being or becoming
hazardous to the public health, safety or welfare. (1977 Code § 8.16.020)
B. No person, firm or corporation shall keep or leave open, or permit or allow to remain open without
suitable safeguards therefor, any cellar door, or well, or cistern, or grating of any vault, or other
opening into any pit, hole, or subterranean chamber, upon any public street, alley or sidewalk
within the corporate limits of the city. (1977 Code § 8.16.030)
5-9-3: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to
a fine as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (2013 Code)
Chapter 10
CLEANUP OF METHAMPHETAMINE LABS
5-10-1: PURPOSES:
The mayor and city council finds and declares that the purposes of this chapter are to ensure that
people are not unnecessarily exposed to the dangers of chemicals used in the production of
methamphetamine, and that proper steps are taken to remove contaminants and assure appropriate
tests are conducted in affected structures to ensure they are sufficiently cleaned for human contact.
The mayor and city council finds that such sites may contain hazardous chemicals, substances, or
residues that place people, particularly children or adults of childbearing age, at risk of exposure
should they inhabit or visit the site. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 160/460
CERTIFIED INDUSTRIAL HYGIENIST: An individual who is certified by the American Board Of
Industrial Hygiene (ABIH) and is in good standing with that board.
ILLEGAL METHAMPHETAMINE LABORATORIES: The areas where methamphetamine has been
manufactured, processed, cooked, disposed of, or stored, and all proximate areas that are likely to be
contaminated as a result of such manufacturing, processing, disposing, or storing.
OWNER: Any person, firm or corporation who holds record fee title, in whole or in part, to the land,
buildings or structures associated with an illegal methamphetamine laboratory.
PROPERTY: Anything that may be the subject of ownership, including, but not limited to, land,
buildings, structures, mobile homes and vehicles. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-3: NOTICE TO OTHER AUTHORITIES:
Law enforcement or other authorities who identify the existence of an illegal methamphetamine
laboratory after the effective date hereof shall promptly notify county department of public health and,
if appropriate, child protection services. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-4: NUISANCE DECLARED:
A property identified as the site of an illegal methamphetamine laboratory shall be declared a public
health nuisance and unfit for human habitation or use. A warning sign shall be posted on the entrance
of the affected part of the property by law enforcement, the city fire chief, and the city code
enforcement officer or his designee. With respect to a vehicle, the warning sign shall be posted on the
front windshield. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-5: OCCUPANCY PROHIBITED:
Upon the issuance and posting of a declaration of public health nuisance, all occupants of such
building or structure shall immediately vacate the premises, and such vehicles shall be impounded by
the police. With the exception of persons evaluating the contamination level, remediating the
contamination, or conducting fire or police activities, no person shall occupy or enter, or allow
occupancy or entrance, to a building or structure which has been declared a public health nuisance,
and no person shall occupy or drive a vehicle which has been declared a public health nuisance until
such declaration is revoked or modified to allow occupancy. All who enter must have the required
health and safety training and wear appropriate personal protective equipment. Removal of the posted
declaration of public health nuisance by anyone other than the city code enforcement officer, the fire
chief or his designee or law enforcement authorities is prohibited. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011; amd. 2013
Code)
5-10-6: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Notice To Owner: The city shall notify the property owner that the property has been declared a
public health nuisance, that the property owner has the right to appeal the declaration to the mayor
and city council, that the city code requires cleanup according to the guidelines, and that the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 161/460
property owner must contract with a certified industrial hygienist to assess the contamination,
oversee the cleanup, and provide a cleanup report; or that, in the alternative, the property owner
may demolish the building or structure.
B. Failure To Abate; Abatement By City: If, after ten (10) days following notice, the city is unable to
obtain any reasonable assurance or plan from the property owner or occupant that the dwelling,
structure or vehicle is being properly vacated, cleaned, remediated and tested, and no appeal has
been requested:
1. A copy of the declaration of public health nuisance may be provided to the lienholders and
mortgage holders of the affected structure and/or properties, and may be recorded with the
clerk.
2. The city may seek to abate the nuisance itself and recover all costs associated with such
abatement.
3. The city may remove the structure or building and assess the whole cost of such removal,
including incidental costs, which assessment shall be a lien against such property until paid.
C. Appeal: Any appeal shall be heard by the mayor and city council within thirty (30) days. Upon a
finding that the declaration was validly issued, the property owner or occupant shall have ten (10)
days to offer reasonable assurance or a plan to the city that the dwelling or structure is being
properly vacated, cleaned, remediated and tested. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-7: AUTHORITY TO MODIFY OR REMOVE NUISANCE DECLARATION:
The code enforcement officer or the fire chief or his designee is authorized to modify the declaration
conditions or to remove the declaration of public health nuisance only after the certified industrial
hygienist submits his or her final report to the city for review and acceptance, and the owner notifies
the code enforcement officer that cleanup has occurred. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-8: PENALTY:
Any person and/or entity violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in section 1-
4-1 of this code per day. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
Chapter 11
DEPOSITS INTO, INTERFERENCE WITH
WATERCOURSES AND DRAINAGE SYSTEMS
5-11-1: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN ACTS:
Unless a permit has been issued as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm,
entity or corporation to:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 162/460
A. Place, deposit, or permit to be placed or deposited any debris, fill, sand, stone or other solid
materials of any kind or nature, or construction of any kind, into or across any stream, ditch,
culvert, pipe, watercourse or other drainage system within the city.
B. Construct and/or place any ditch, pipe, culvert or artificial watercourse of any kind or nature which
shall collect and direct the flow of natural surface waters or drainage, or increase in intensity or
quantity the flow of surface waters or drainage, from paved surfaces, structures, roads or
improvements directly into any stream, ditch, culvert, pipe or watercourse or other drainage system
in the city.
C. Fill, obstruct, dam, divert or otherwise change or alter the natural or artificial flow of waters or
drainage, or the intensity or quantity of flow, through any stream, ditch, pipe, culvert, watercourse
or other improvements or drainage system with the city. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
5-11-2: PERMIT APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL:
A. All applicants for a permit to do any of the acts set forth in section 5-11-1 of this chapter shall
submit a proposal to the city code enforcement officer who will determine if plans and
specifications prepared by a licensed professional engineer should be required. If it is determined
such plans and specifications are not required, the code enforcement officer may recommend to
the city council that a permit be issued. If it is determined such plans and specifications should be
required, the code enforcement officer, after review of plans and specifications submitted to him,
may recommend to the city council that the permit may be issued.
B. When an application for a permit to do any of the acts set forth in section 5-11-1 of this chapter that
would affect land lying partly without the area requiring approval of subdivision or site
development, then a separate plan shall be prepared for that affected land and filed with the city
clerk who will forward such plan to the code enforcement officer for review and, if need be, submit
to the city engineer.
C. If review by the city engineer is deemed appropriate, the city engineer shall report the results of his
review to the code enforcement officer who shall make a recommendation to the city council to
approve or deny the application. The city council shall advise the city clerk of its decision within
fourteen (14) days after receipt of the recommendation of the code enforcement officer. If the
application for permit is approved, the city clerk shall issue the permit. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
5-11-3: TOXIC OR HAZARDOUS WASTES PROHIBITED:
No toxic waste or hazardous material shall be deposited in any watercourse or drainage system with
the city. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
5-11-4: CORRECTION OF EXISTING CONDITIONS:
Except as hereinafter provided, all existing obstructions, dams, diversions, construction of any kind,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 163/460
deposits of debris, fill, sand, stone, logs, trees or other solid materials, or other alterations or
diversions of the natural flow of water or the intensity or quantity of flow through, across or to any
stream, ditch, culvert, watercourse or other drainage system within the city which:
A. Causes the inundation of real property and/or buildings on other premises; or
B. Constitutes an undue burden upon the official drainage system or hampers the proper present or
future course of development of the official drainage system; or
C. Presently constitutes, or in the reasonably foreseeable future will constitute, a danger or hazard to
the well being, safety or general welfare of the residents of the city of any property located therein;
or
D. Obstructs the natural flow of water;
shall be removed or corrected by the owners of the premises upon which said obstructions, dams,
diversion, construction, deposits or other alterations of the natural flow of water are situated, within
thirty (30) days after written notice to remove or correct same. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
5-11-5: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The requirement that a permit must be issued before engaging in any of the acts specified in sections
5-11-1 and 5-11-4 of this chapter shall not apply to works to be done pursuant to the authority of an
agency of the state, federal or other government entity. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
5-11-6: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A. Notice Of Violation: Any person, firm, entity or corporation found to be violating any provision of this
chapter shall be served with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a thirty
(30) day time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period
stated in such notice, correct or remove all violations. (Ord. 2283, 9-21-2009)
B. Penalty: Any person, firm, or corporation who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided in subsection A of this section shall be deemed guilty of a city ordinance violation and
shall be fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each violation. Each day the condition
exists after the thirty (30) day notice is received shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 2283,
9-21-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
Title 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 164/460
Chapter 1
POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS
6-1-1: APPOINTMENT OF POLICE CHIEF AND FIRE CHIEF:
The chief of police and the chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council, and said appointments need not be made from the members of
the police and fire departments, respectively. (1977 Code § 2.08.040; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1-2: REGISTRY LISTS:
A. Commencing with the expiration of the current registry lists for candidates for employment as city
police officers or firefighters, the fire and police merit board shall conduct examinations annually for
candidates to be enrolled in the registry lists.
B. The names of qualified candidates shall remain on the registry lists for two (2) years.
C. The fire and police merit board shall have the discretion of selecting names for employment from
those on lists up to two (2) years or on the most recently compiled lists. (Ord. 2253, 4-13-2009)
6-1-3: PREEMPLOYMENT CONTRACT:
A. Any applicant for a position in the fire department or the police department must agree to the
following conditions at the time of making application for such position: that should he/she be hired
as an employee of the city police or fire department, he/she will not voluntarily or involuntarily
separate from the employ of the city for a minimum of thirty six (36) months from the date of hire,
otherwise, he/she will remunerate the city for any and all costs incurred as enumerated in
subsection B of this section at the following rate: One hundred percent (100%), if separation is
prior to thirty six (36) months having elapsed from date of hire.
B. Schedule of costs which may be incurred by the city are: (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999)
1. Any preentry medical examination required by the city police and firefighters' pension funds.
(Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
2. Basic training, including Fire Fighter Recruit Academy and Police Training Institute Recruit
Academy, including lodging, meals and travel expenses.
C. The obligations under the required agreement shall terminate after the completion of thirty six (36)
months from the date of hire. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999)
D. The agreement shall contain a statement that the applicant understands that employment with the
city is contingent upon his/her completion of a probationary period of twelve (12) months and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 165/460
continued performance to the satisfaction of the city. Nothing contained herein shall be construed
as a promise or agreement by the city to retain the applicant as an employee of the city for thirty
six (36) months or any portion thereof or thereafter. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
E. The city does not, by the agreement, waive any of the rights, privileges, or prerogatives it
possesses now or hereafter in effect.
F. The applicant acknowledges that he/she has examined the agreement that he/she has read and
understands the agreement, and he/she has the right to consult an attorney prior to entering the
agreement. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999)
6-1-4: MANDATORY RETIREMENT AGE:
A. Established: There is established a mandatory retirement age for all police officers and firefighters
now in the service of the city and for all police officers and firefighters who may hereafter enter the
service of the city. (1977 Code § 2.68.010)
B. Designated: The age at which such police officers and firefighters must retire from the service of
the city is designated to be sixty five (65) years. (1977 Code § 2.68.020)
C. Time For Retirement: Any police officer or firefighter shall be retired effective at the close of the first
regular pay period after such police officer or firefighter reaches his sixty fifth birthday. (1977 Code
§ 2.68.030)
6-1-5: SOLICITING, RECEIPT OF FUNDS OR EQUIPMENT FOR POLICE OR FIRE
DEPARTMENT:
A. No solicitation for money, directly or indirectly, in the name of or in behalf of the city police
department or the city fire department, expressed or implied, shall be conducted within the city by
mail, by telephone, in person or otherwise without the prior approval of the city council.
B. Neither the city police department nor the city fire department nor the personnel of either
department may receive money or equipment for use by or use in the respective departments from
any individual, organization or entity without the prior approval of the city council.
C. Personnel employed in the city police department or the city fire department are prohibited from
engaging in the solicitation of money or equipment, directly or indirectly, for use in or by either
department without the prior approval of the city council. (Ord. 1702, 10-19-1998)
ARTICLE A. POLICE DEPARTMENT
6-1A-1: ESTABLISHED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 166/460
There is established a police department of the city which shall consist of such officers of the city as
are by law clothed with police powers, a chief of police, and such other police officers as the city
council shall, from time to time by ordinance or resolution, prescribe. (1977 Code § 2.24.010; amd.
2013 Code)
6-1A-2: SUPERVISION:
The police force of the city shall be under the immediate supervision of the commissioner of public
health and safety of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.100)
6-1A-3: JURISDICTION OF POLICE AND FIRE MERIT BOARD; EXEMPTIONS:
A. All personnel in the city police department are certified to be subject to and under the jurisdiction of
the police and fire merit board to the extent provided by law. The offices of chief of police and
assistant chief of police remain exempt from and outside the purview of the jurisdiction of the
police and fire merit board. In the event any person holding the office of chief of police returns to
the ranks of sworn personnel, that individual will revert to and be under the jurisdiction of the police
and fire merit board. (Ord. 1657, 6-23-1997; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Those employees of the city police department holding the supervisory positions of chief and
assistant chief are hereby specifically excepted and exempted from any collective bargaining unit
that is now or that may hereafter be formed by the members of the department. (Ord. 1097, 12-30-
1985; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF:
A. Generally: The chief of police shall superintend the police force of the city and have the custody,
care and control of the public property of the police department, subject to the directions of the
commissioner of public health and safety and the city council, and of all firearms and other
equipment thereof. It shall be his duty to preserve the peace, order, safety and cleanliness of the
city, and to this end, he shall execute or cause to be executed and enforced all orders of the city
council. He shall be charged with the duty of protecting the rights of persons and property and
cause to be enforced all ordinances of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.020; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Health Duties: The chief of police shall execute or cause to be executed all orders directed to him
by the commissioner of public health and safety so far as they relate to the preservation of the
health and safety of the people of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.030; amd. 2013 Code)
C. Reports: The chief of police shall, at the first meeting of the city council in May of each year, make
an annual report in writing to the city council of the state of the police force with a detailed report of
the transactions of the police department for the preceding year with such statistics and
suggestions in regard to the requirements of said department as he may deem advisable, and shall
also make reports of any matter or thing concerning such department whenever requested by the
commissioner of public health and safety or by the city council. (1977 Code § 2.24.090)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 167/460
6-1A-5: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
A. Serving Warrants: The chief of police and any regular or other police officer shall have power and
authority and it shall be his duty to serve and execute within the city warrants and other processes
for the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with the violation of any city ordinance,
or any crime, misdemeanor or offense against the peace of the state of Illinois or the city, or held
for examination or trial, or taken on execution for the commission of any crime, misdemeanor or
violation of any law or ordinance of the city, and while serving or executing or assisting in the
service or execution of any such warrant or process as aforesaid, he shall be vested with and have
all the powers and authority conferred upon sheriffs by the common law and laws of the state of
Illinois. (1977 Code § 2.24.040; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Assist Fire Department: It shall be the duty of the police force to aid the fire department by giving
alarms in case of fire and by clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of any fire so
that the members of the fire department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of
their duty. (1977 Code § 2.24.060)
C. Arrests: The several members of the police force are severally authorized to arrest, with or without
process or on view, any person who breaks the peace or is found violating any ordinance of the
city or any criminal law of the state of Illinois, and to take such person before the proper judge or, if
necessary, detain such person in custody overnight or Sunday or any legal holiday in the county
jail or other qualified place of incarceration until he can be brought before the proper judge for trial.
(1977 Code § 2.24.070; amd. 2013 Code)
D. Court Duties: All police officers of the city making arrests shall attend as witnesses before the court
where the trial may be had and shall procure all necessary evidence in their power and furnish a
list of witnesses to the court and the prosecuting attorney. (1977 Code § 2.24.080; amd. 2013
Code)
6-1A-6: POLICE PENSION FUND AND BOARD:
A. State Regulations Apply: The provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., "police
pension fund - municipalities 500,000 and under", are in force and effect in the city. (1977 Code
§ 2.60.010; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Board Of Trustees: The mayor of the city is authorized and directed to appoint two (2) members to
serve upon the board of trustees to administer the police pension fund, one of whom shall serve
until the second Tuesday in May 1955, and the other to serve until the second Tuesday in May
1956, and the two (2) trustees so appointed shall call an election to be held as provided in the act
to choose the other members of the board of trustees. Each such trustee shall serve a term of
three (3) years which terms shall be staggered. (1977 Code § 2.60.030; amd. 2013 Code)
C. Treasurer:
1. The city finance director-treasurer shall be the treasurer and custodian of the police pension
fund and shall make disbursements therefrom only at the direction of and on the authority of the
board of trustees. (1977 Code § 2.60.040; amd. 2013 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 168/460
2. The city finance director-treasurer shall set aside for the police pension fund the monies
provided to be set aside by the act designated in subsection A of this section. (1977 Code
§ 2.60.020; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1A-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The rules and regulations of the police department, as set out in ordinance 1407, as amended, are
hereby adopted by reference. A copy of said rules and regulations is on file in the office of the city
clerk for public use and inspection. (2013 Code)
6-1A-8: RESISTING, HINDERING POLICE PROHIBITED:
Whoever, within the city, resists any member of the police force or any other person duly authorized to
do police duty, in the discharge of his duty, or in any way interferes with, prevents or hinders in the
discharge of his duty as such member, or attempts to do so, or whoever in any manner assists any
person in the custody of any member of the police force to escape or to attempt to escape from such
custody, or attempts to rescue any person from such custody, shall be fined as provided in section 1-
4-1 of this code. (1977 Code § 2.24.050; amd. 2013 Code)
ARTICLE B. FIRE DEPARTMENT
6-1B-1: JURISDICTION OF POLICE AND FIRE MERIT BOARD; EXEMPTIONS:
A. All personnel in the city fire department are certified to be subject to and under the jurisdiction of
the police and fire merit board to the extent provided by law. The office of fire chief remains exempt
from and outside the purview of the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board. In the event any
person holding the office of fire chief returns to the ranks of sworn personnel, that individual will
revert to and be under the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board. (Ord. 1657, 6-23-1997;
amd. 2013 Code)
B. The city does hereby recognize the Marion Professional Firefighters Local 2977 of the International
Association Of Firefighters AFL-CIO-CLC as the exclusive bargaining representative for all full time
employees of the city fire department, excluding the chief, for the purpose of collective bargaining,
and establishing and administering a written labor agreement covering wages, rates of pay, hours
of labor, and all other terms and conditions of employment. (Ord. 1111, 3-31-1986)
6-1B-2: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND AND BOARD:
A. State Regulations Apply: The provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-101 et seq.,
"firefighters' pension fund - municipalities 500,000 and under", are in force and effect in the city.
(1977 Code § 2.64.010; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Board Of Trustees:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 169/460
1. Created; Composition: There is hereby created the board of trustees of the firefighters' pension
fund. The membership of the board shall be as follows: the city finance director-treasurer, the
city clerk, the fire chief, the mayor, three (3) persons from the ranks of active firefighters and one
person who has retired under the firefighters' pension fund act of 1919.
2. Elected Members:
a. The members chosen from the active and retired firefighters shall be elected by ballot at
elections to be held on the third Monday in April of the applicable years under the Australian
ballot system, at such place or places in the city, and under such regulations as shall be
prescribed by the board.
b. No person shall cast more than one vote for each candidate for whom he or she is eligible to
vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from the active firefighters, all active
firefighters and no others may vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from
retired firefighters, the retired firefighters and no others may vote.
c. Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term of three (3) years and until
his or her successor has been duly elected and qualified.
d. The board shall canvass the ballots and declare which persons have been elected and for
what term or terms respectively. In case of a tie vote between two (2) or more candidates, the
board shall determine by lot which candidate or candidates have been elected and for what
term or terms respectively. In the event of the failure, resignation, or inability to act of any
board member, a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election called
by the board and conducted in the same manner as a regular election.
3. President And Secretary: The board shall elect annually from its members a president and
secretary.
4. Compensation: Board members shall not receive or have any right to receive any salary from a
pension fund for services performed as board members. (2013 Code)
C. Treasurer:
1. The city finance director-treasurer shall be treasurer and custodian of the firefighters' pension
fund and shall make disbursements thereof only at the direction of and the authorization of the
board of trustees. (1977 Code § 2.64.040; amd. 2013 Code)
2. The city finance director-treasurer shall set aside for the firefighters' pension fund the monies
provided to be set aside by the act designated in subsection A of this section from time to time
as required by law. (1977 Code § 2.64.020; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1B-3: NONRESIDENT FEES FOR DEPARTMENT SERVICES:
A. Established:
1. Any nonresident of the city who receives service from the city fire department personnel and city
emergency equipment, including the "jaws of life", while within the corporate limits of the city
shall pay a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
2. Any nonresident of the city who receives service from the city fire department personnel and city
emergency equipment, including the "jaws of life", outside the corporate limits of the city shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 170/460
pay a fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
B. Copies Of Provisions: Copies of reports of the providing of the services indicated in subsection A of
this section will be made available by the fire department upon payment of five dollars ($5.00) for
each copy. (Ord. 1568, 9-5-1995)
6-1B-4: HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES SPILLS:
A. Immediate Response Required: The city fire department is authorized and directed to respond,
immediately upon being notified, and to do all things within its capabilities to contain, remove and
dispose of any material hazardous to public health and safety that is leaked, spilled or otherwise
improperly released within the corporate limits of the city or within a reasonable distance thereof.
(Ord. 1570, 9-11-1995; amd. Ord. 2275, 7-20-2009)
B. Contract For Services: Should such response require the services of special personnel and
equipment beyond the capabilities of the city fire department to provide, the chief of the fire
department is authorized to obtain or to contract for the services of personnel or equipment
sufficient to contain, remove and dispose of such hazardous materials.
C. Responsibility For Costs: The costs incurred for the use of such special personnel and equipment,
in addition to the costs of the use of city personnel and equipment, shall be charged to the person,
firm or organization, jointly and severally, in possession of, in the process of transporting or
otherwise responsible for the containment of any hazardous material spilled, leaked or otherwise
improperly released.
D. Costs Established: The amount of the costs incurred by the city from the use of special personnel
and equipment are the amounts to be charged the person, firm or organization designated in
subsection C of this section. In addition, such person, firm or organization shall be charged for the
use of city personnel, equipment and materials as follows:
Pumper truck $300.00 per hour
Aerial ladder truck 300.00 per hour
Communications unit 300.00 per hour
Hazardous materials truck 300.00 per hour
Off duty personnel call back Hourly overtime rate, plus 30 percent
Other personnel Regular hourly rate
Materials Cost of replacement
Other equipment Regular hourly rate
(Ord. 1570, 9-11-1995)
