No alcohol, drugs or controlled substances of any nature shall be permitted upon the premises of the
center at any time, nor shall anyone in a state of intoxication be allowed to remain therein. (Ord. 1137,
1-19-1987)
8-5-5: FEES AND CHARGES:
Admission to the center building and facilities shall be free to all citizens of the city, although moderate
and reasonable fees may be charged for meals provided, if any, materials used in handicraft projects,
and for other programs or activities of a special nature. (Ord. 1137, 1-19-1987)
Chapter 6
TREES, SHRUBS AND PLANTS
8-6-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
A. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote and protect the public health, safety, and general
welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs,
and other plants within the city.
B. This chapter provides full power and authority over all trees, plants and shrubs located within street
rights of way, parks and public places of the city; and to trees, plants and shrubs located on private
property that constitute a hazard or threat as described herein. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
8-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words, phrases, terms and their derivations shall have
the meanings given herein. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any
kind.
TREE: A tree in a public place, except where otherwise indicated. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
8-6-3: CITY JURISDICTION AND SUPERVISION:
A. The mayor, or his designee, shall have exclusive jurisdiction and supervision over all trees, other
plants, and grassy areas planted or growing in public places. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
B. The mayor, or his designee, shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to issue orders to
plant, trim, spray, preserve and remove trees, other plants and grassy areas in public places to
ensure safety or preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public places. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992;
amd. 2013 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 276/460
C. The mayor, or his designee, shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to order the trimming,
preservation or removal of trees or plants upon private property when he shall find such action is
necessary to public safety or to prevent the spread of disease or insects to public trees and places.
(Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
D. The mayor, or his designee, shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to supervise or direct
another to supervise all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this
chapter. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992; amd. 2013 Code)
E. It shall be public policy of the city to plant trees in accordance with a uniform plan to be determined
by the mayor, or his designee, along rights of way of all new or reconstructed streets, and where
other public improvements cause trees to be removed.
F. The mayor, or his designee, shall have the authority to affix reasonable conditions to the grant of a
permit hereunder. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
8-6-4: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required; Duty To Remove Debris: No person shall plant, set out, trim, spray, preserve or
remove trees or other plants in public places without first filing an application and procuring a
permit from the mayor, or his designee. Any person granted a permit to cut down or trim a tree in a
public place shall remove all the debris at his own expense.
B. Standards For Issuance; Contents: The mayor, or his designee, shall issue the permit provided
herein when he finds that the desired action or treatment is necessary and that the proposed
method and workmanship are satisfactory. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of
expiration, and the work shall be completed in the time allowed on the permit and in the manner
therein described. Any permit shall be void if the terms are violated.
C. Conditions: Work done under a permit issued hereunder shall be performed in strict accordance
with the terms hereof and with the following regulations established for the planting, trimming and
care of trees in public places:
1. Trees must not be less than one inch (1") in diameter of a trunk one foot (1') above the ground.
2. All trees from one to three inches (3") in diameter of a trunk one foot (1') above the ground must
be protected and supported by tree guards.
3. No tree shall be placed so as, in the opinion of the mayor, or his designee, to cause a traffic
hazard.
4. In felling trees, the same must be removed with the root stump grubbed out when so required by
the mayor, or his designee.
5. All cuts above one inch (1") in diameter must be waterproofed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 277/460
6. Trees shall be planted at least thirty feet (30') apart except where a special permit is obtained
from the mayor, or his designee.
7. No tree shall be planted where the clear space between the curb and the sidewalk is less than
three feet (3').
8. No tree or shrub shall be planted nearer than one foot (1') from the curb line or the sidewalk
unless a special permit is granted by the mayor, or his designee. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
9. No tree, bush or shrub shall be planted or be allowed to remain untrimmed so as to be an
obstruction to vision at a street or alley corner.
10. No tree shall be planted on any public way except of the variety approved by the mayor, or his
designee. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992; amd. 2013 Code)
8-6-5: RESPONSIBILITIES OF PERSONS PLANTING TREES:
A. It shall be the duty of any person growing a tree within the public highway, or responsible for trees
growing on property abutting on public places supporting trees or plants, or on private property:
(Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
1. To trim his trees so as not to cause a hazard to public places or interfere with the proper lighting
of public highways by the streetlights and so that the minimum clearance of any portion
overhanging a public way shall be at least eight feet (8'). (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992; amd. 2013
Code)
2. To treat or remove any tree or plant so diseased or insect ridden as to constitute a hazard to
trees or plants in public places.
3. To remove any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall.
4. To trim bushes and shrubs so that they do not obstruct passage on any portion of any sidewalk.
(Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
B. The mayor, or his designee, may cause to be trimmed or removed any tree or shrub so that any
obstruction or danger to traffic or passage shall be eliminated. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992; amd. 2013
Code)
8-6-6: PROCEDURE UPON ORDER TO REMOVE:
A. Notice To Remove: When the mayor, or his designee, shall find it necessary to order the trimming,
preservation or removal of trees or plants upon private property as authorized in subsection 8-6-1B
of this chapter, he shall serve a written order to correct the dangerous condition upon the owner,
operator, occupant or other person responsible for its existence. The order required herein shall be
served in one of the following ways:
1. By making personal delivery of the order to the person responsible.
2. By leaving the order with some person of suitable age and discretion upon the premises.
3. By affixing a copy of the order to the door at the entrance of the premises in violation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 278/460
4. By mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the owner of the premises, by
registered mail.
B. Time For Compliance: The order required herein shall set forth a time limit for compliance,
dependent upon the hazard and danger created by the violation.
C. Appeal From Order: A person to whom an order hereunder is directed shall have the right, within
twenty four (24) hours of the service of such order, to appeal to the city council by filing written
notice of such appeal to the city clerk. The city council shall review such order and appeal at its
next regularly scheduled meeting and render its decision thereon. Unless the order is revoked or
modified, it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by the person to whom directed.
D. Failure To Comply; Removal By City: When a person to whom an order is directed fails to comply
within the specified time, the mayor, or his designee, shall remedy the condition or contract with
others for such purpose and charge the cost thereof to the person to whom the order is directed.
The person remedying a condition under a contract made hereunder shall be authorized to enter
the premises for that purpose. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992)
8-6-7: DAMAGE TO, TAMPERING WITH PUBLIC TREES PROHIBITED:
Unless specifically authorized by permit, no person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant,
or remove any tree on public property; attach any wire, nails, advertising posters, or other contrivance
to any tree; allow any liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with
them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or the heat from such fire might injure any
portion of any tree. (Ord. 1432, 2-24-1992; amd. 2013 Code)
8-6-8: PENALTY:
Violation of any provision of this chapter shall result in a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). (2013 Code)
Chapter 7
MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS
8-7-1: CITY OF MARION LAKE HOURS:
The city of Marion Lake will be open to visitors from four thirty o'clock (4:30) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. daily. Anyone found trespassing on lake property after closing will be fined not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2214, 7-14-2008)
8-7-2: ADVERTISING RESTRICTIONS ON CLOCK TOWER PROPERTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 279/460
The placement of banners, placards, signs and other such material on the grounds surrounding the
clock tower on the Tower Square is prohibited. Upon application to the mayor, an exception may be
approved. (Ord. 2238, 12-8-2008)
Title 9
WATER AND SEWER
Chapter 1
GENERAL WATER AND SEWER PROVISIONS
9-1-1: FISCAL YEAR FOR WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENTS:
The "fiscal year" for the water department and sewer department of the city shall hereafter commence
on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of each succeeding year. (Ord. 1472, 3-22-1993, eff. 4-30-
1993)
9-1-2: IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM:
A. Program Adopted: The identity theft prevention program has been adopted by the city in
compliance with the fair and accurate credit transactions act of 2003. The program is designed to
detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft in connection with the opening of or access to any water
or sewer services account.
B. Implementation And Administration: The identity theft prevention program shall be implemented
and administered by the city finance director-treasurer as the program administrator. (Ord. 2231,
10-27-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
C. Changes To Program: Changes to the identity theft prevention program of a day to day operational
character and decisions relating to the interpretation and implementation of the program may be
made by the program administrator. However, major changes or shifts of policy positions under the
program shall only be made by the city council. (Ord. 2231, 10-27-2008)
9-1-3: WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS:
A. Duty To Connect: It is made the duty of the owners of all real estate abutting upon or touching the
line of any proposed improvements to make all contemplated private connections with public
sewers and water mains before the work on any such streets or alleys is completed by the
contractor; which connections shall be made under the inspection and with the approval of the
sewer and water superintendents. (1977 Code § 13.04.010; amd. 2013 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 280/460
B. Permit Required; Bond: All persons, firms and corporations shall, after the completion of said
improvement, be debarred from making any opening or excavation on said street or alley, upon or
along the line of said improvement, without first obtaining the permission of the city code
enforcement officer, and no permission shall be granted until the person, firm or corporation
applying therefor shall give bond to the city in such sum as may be fixed by the city council, to be
approved by the mayor, conditioned for the filling up and restoration of any part of such
improvement or pavement in as good condition as before such openings or excavations were
made, and pay the expenses of inspecting the work and making connections.
C. Plans And Specifications:
1. All such work shall be done in accordance with the plans and specifications for any such
improvement, which shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk.
2. All of said private connections with said public water mains shall be of material approved by the
water superintendent extending from the water main to property line.
D. Approval And Acceptance: All such work thus done shall be subject to the approval and
acceptance of the code enforcement officer or other authorized officer. (1977 Code § 13.04.020;
amd. 2013 Code)
Chapter 2
WATER USE AND SERVICE1
9-2-1: DEFINITION OF PREMISES:
A "premises", as contemplated in this chapter, is defined as follows:
A. A building under one roof owned by one party and occupied as one business or residence; or
B. A combination of buildings owned by one party in one common enclosure occupied by one family or
business; or
C. The one side of a double house having a solid vertical partition wall; or
D. Each floor of a house where each such floor is tenanted as a separate residence; or
E. A building owned by one party having a number of apartments or offices and using halls and
entrances in common. (1977 Code § 13.60.120)
9-2-2: WATER TAPS AND FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 281/460
A. Tap Fees Established: There are hereby established the following fees for tapping into the water
mains of the city of Marion, Illinois, where its mains are now or may hereafter be laid in a street or
alley adjoining property where water service is desired, and a service pipe is required for
immediate and continuous service:
1. For a fee of eight hundred dollars ($800.00), paid in advance, the water department will make a
tap three-fourths inch (3/4") in diameter into the main, extend the service pipe from such tap sixty
feet (60') or to the property line of the consumer, if not more than sixty feet (60'), and install a
meter box ready for a meter to be set. For a distance of more than sixty feet (60'), the consumer
will be obligated for the additional cost per foot.
2. For a fee of nine hundred dollars ($900.00), paid in advance, the water department will make a
tap one inch (1") in diameter into the main, extend the service pipe from such tap sixty feet (60')
or to the property line of the consumer, if not more than sixty feet (60'), and install a meter box
ready for meter to be set. For a distance of more than sixty feet (60'), the consumer will be
obligated for the additional cost per foot.
3. For a fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), paid in advance, the water department will make
a tap two inches (2") in diameter into the main, extend the service pipe from such tap sixty feet
(60') or to the property line of the consumer, if not more than sixty feet (60'), and install a valve
and valve box. For a distance of more than sixty feet (60'), the consumer will be obligated for the
additional cost per foot.
4. For a fee of four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00), paid in advance, the water department will grant
permission to make a tap in excess of two inches (2") in diameter, provided any person receiving
permission to make such tap will make the tap, furnish all materials necessary in connection
therewith and provide a meter approved by the water department superintendent.
5. Persons desiring a lateral line from a main line will pay four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) in
advance for a connection at the main and such persons will extend the lateral line from the main
line at their expense. Taps made off lateral lines will come under the provisions set out in
subsections A1, A2 and A3 of this section. All lateral lines must meet the approval of the water
department superintendent as to size and other specifications.
6. The water department will furnish meters for one inch (1") and three-fourths inch (3/4") taps as
hereinabove indicated. The property owner will furnish all meters of larger dimensions.
7. Any tap made by a contractor or developer on a water main subject to a rebate agreement
entered into by the city must make the payment required by such agreement in addition to such
other regular charges as may be required.
8. In the event a property owner or contractor desires to make a tap of the dimensions set out in
subsection A1, A2 or A3 of this section, such owner or contractor may make such tap upon
payment of one-half (1/2) the fee indicated and after receiving permission from the
superintendent of the water department. (Ord. 3202, 8-11-2014, eff. 9-1-2014)
9-2-3: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP OR OCCUPANCY:
A. Application For Service: All persons, firms or corporations desiring water service must make written
application at the office of the water department on printed forms provided therefor, setting forth in
said application all purposes for which water may be used upon their premises in order that proper
rates and assessments can be made. (1977 Code § 13.60.010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 282/460
B. Change Of Ownership Or Occupancy; Liability For Service: In the event of a change in ownership
or occupancy of any premises, each subsequent owner or occupant of said premises must make
application for service at the office of the water department, but the former applicant or consumer
of water shall remain liable for water furnished to said premises until he has given notice in writing
to the department to discontinue the supply. (1977 Code § 13.60.070)
9-2-4: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE:
A. Available Mains: Where its mains are now or may hereafter be laid, the water department will install
the service pipe and appurtenances between the water main and the property line; provided,
however, that the water main is in a street or alley adjoining property where water service is
desired, and provided also, that the service pipe is required for immediate and continuous service.
The water department will, at its expense, furnish all labor necessary to install service. However, all
persons, firms, corporations, etc., for whom a service pipe is laid must pay the water department
for all material used in the connection of service, including street repair.
B. No Mains Available: Where there are no mains adjoining property where water service is required,
the property owner shall dig all the ditch from the street or alley where the water main is located to
said property where service is required. The ditch shall be a minimum of thirty inches (30") deep.
The water department will tap the main and run the service up to the street or alley property line
and install a curb stop and curb box.
C. Responsibility For Costs: All material used in said service shall be paid for by the property owner.
However, the water department will furnish up to fifty feet (50') of pipe on a private service where
said service is laid in the street or alley, and the property owner or consumer shall furnish the
balance of pipe required to run service from the curb stop to the property where service is desired.
D. Maintenance: The water department will maintain such service pipes and appurtenances laid
thereby; except, however, the water department will not install at its expense nor maintain service
pipes to supply water for the extinguishment of fire. (1977 Code § 13.60.020)
E. Water Main Requirements:
1. Purpose:
a. The purpose of this subsection E is to establish the size of water mains to be installed in the
city forward from the date hereof. Such water mains shall be of sufficient size to promote the
volume of water required to meet the expected needs of the area to be served whether it be
for residential, commercial or industrial purposes.
b. Regardless of the area it is expected water mains will have the capacity to transmit sufficient
volumes of water to provide reasonable fire protection.
2. Size: The minimum size water mains to be installed in proposed residential areas shall be six
inches (6"). The minimum size water mains to be installed in proposed or existing commercial or
industrial areas shall be eight inches (8").
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 283/460
3. Backflow Prevention: When installation of a backflow prevention device is required the device
and the installation thereof shall meet the standards prescribed by the Illinois plumbing code.
4. Approval Of Size And Location: The chief of the fire department shall approve the size of any
proposed water main before installation and assure the location for such water main has been
approved.
5. Fire Hydrants: The chief of the fire department shall determine the number and location of fire
hydrants required to be installed in any area proposed for development. In addition, the chief of
the fire department shall approve before installation in any structure the proposed fire prevention
system to assure compliance with the requirements of the Illinois plumbing code. (Ord. 3229, 1-
12-2015)
6. Building Permit: No commercial building permit may be issued until the chief of the fire
department has certified compliance with the provisions of this subsection E. (Ord. 3229, 1-12-
2015; amd. Ord. 3249, 4-13-2015)
7. Violation: Any violation of the provisions of this subsection E may subject the violator to a fine of
not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation continues shall be
considered a separate offense. (Ord. 3229, 1-12-2015)
9-2-5: SERVICE REGULATIONS:
A. All taps and connections to distributing mains of the water department shall be made by and under
the direction of the water superintendent or other authorized employee of the water department
and not otherwise.
B. No premises will be supplied by more than one service pipe, except in cases where water is taken
for the extinguishment of fire, in which event, water must be taken through a separate service pipe
and used solely for firefighting purposes. This subsection applies only to places of business.
C. All service pipes must have placed thereon a stop and waste cock immediately inside the building
or foundation wall at a place where the pipeline enters. All service pipe shall be laid at a minimum
depth of two and one-half feet (21/2') and shall not be laid in sewer ditches, nor driveways, nor
pass through premises other than that to be supplied. The property owner may be required to lay
his service pipe to the property line at a point designated by the superintendent or other authorized
employee of the water department before the water department shall be required to connect such
service pipe with the water main. Where two (2) pieces of property join and both property owners
desire service, one service pipe may be laid and a meter and cover installed on the property line
dividing the properties with two (2) meter yokes in meter tile, one for each property. In the event a
meter tile or cover is broken, or lid is missing, the property owner must bear the expense of
replacing same.
D. The water department reserves the right to determine the size of each connection to its mains, also
the size and kind of service pipe to be laid to each premises, and the location of its water meter.
Where the water meter is inside a building and hard to read, the water department shall have the
right to move its water meter into the yard and charge the property owner for the meter box and
cover. The water department is to bear the expense of labor and material necessary to move the
meter into the yard, except for the meter box and cover. (1977 Code § 13.60.030)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 284/460
9-2-6: SERVICE LINES OWNED BY PROPERTY OWNER:
A. Service pipe installed and owned by the property owner must, at the property owner's expense, be
kept and maintained in good condition and free from all leaks; and for failure to do so, the water
supply may be discontinued.
B. The water department shall in no event be responsible for damage done by water escaping from a
service pipe or fixtures on the premises of the owner or consumer. The owner of a service pipe
must, at his own expense, make additions thereto or changes therein which may be required on
account of change in street grade.
C. A service pipe, as referred to in this chapter, consists of all pipes, fittings, valves, stop and waste
cocks, etc., installed past the first stop valve from the main. (1977 Code § 13.60.040)
9-2-7: METERS:
A. Authority To Place Meters: The water department has the right to place a meter upon any service
pipe and charge for water service by meter measurement. (1977 Code § 13.64.010)
B. Installation And Maintenance; Size And Location:
1. All meters, except detector devices, shall be installed, maintained and renewed by and at the
expense of the water department, but in case of damage to such meters by reason of any act,
neglect or omission on the part of the consumer, such as damages occasioned by fire, frost, hot
water, accident or misuse, the consumer shall pay to the water department the cost of its repair
on presentation of a bill therefor.
2. The water department reserves the right to determine the size of meter that shall be placed on
any service pipe and the location of said meter. (1977 Code § 13.64.020)
C. Pit Specifications:
1. Established: There are hereby established specifications for the construction of water meter pits
for one and one-fourth inch (11/4") to eight inch (8") meters.
a. Size:
4 feet long
3 feet wide - inside dimensions
3 feet deep
b. Material:
Mortared concrete block walls (6 inch hollow block) or
6 inch poured concrete walls
4 inch poured concrete floor with sump hole
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 285/460
c. Sump Hole:
8 inches x 8 inches square or 8 inch diameter round hole located in the corner of meter pit
floor
d. Lids:
(1) Large lid: Removable lid - recessed or angle-iron reinforced lid, sized to cover the outside
dimensions of the box and fitted to prevent the large lid from slipping off
Lid to be constructed of:
1/4 inch steel (no traffic)
1/2 inch steel (with traffic)
(2) Small lid:
Hinged onto the large lid
11/2 feet square lid
Positioned directly over meter registers
e. Bypass: To be located inside the meter pit if the meter size is 11/4 inches, 11/2 inches or 2
inches
To be located outside the meter pit if meter size is 4 inches, 6 inches or 8 inches
f. Valves: If the bypass is inside the box, a hand operated gate valve is acceptable
If the bypass is outside the box, 2 inch square nut valves with 51/4 inch valve box is
acceptable
g. Compound Meters: Compound meters only on 2 inches and up
2. Exceptions: Any changes to any part of the specifications set out in subsection C1 of this section
must be approved by the superintendent of the city water department prior to construction. (Ord.
1146, 4-13-1987)
D. Meter Deposits:
1. All consumers taking or desiring to take water by meter measurement must keep on deposit with
the water department at all times the following sum or sums for each single premises:
a. For laundromats, factories, department stores, bottling plants, car wash establishments,
hospitals, hotels/motels/inns, nursing homes, retirement homes and mobile home parks:
Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
b. For apartment houses with more than three (3) apartments, restaurants, service stations, or
body shops with car washing facilities: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
c. For rental units in which landlord pays for the water service, the deposit for every fifty (50)
units: Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 286/460
d. For single-family homes, apartments or businesses (containing only 2 bathroom facilities):
One hundred dollars ($100.00).
2. Provided, however, where the amount set forth in this subsection is not sufficient to protect the
water department, an amount may be required based on the consumer's estimated bill figured
for that service for a billing period plus ninety (90) days.
3. The consumer's deposit must be kept intact and the water department shall not be required to
apply it to payment of current water bills or any other charges incurred by the consumer.
4. There will be a thirty dollar ($30.00) fee for any return checks.
5. In the event service is scheduled to be disconnected due to nonpayment, the consumer will be
charged a reconnect fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) with an additional five dollars ($5.00) for each
occurrence thereafter, capped at sixty dollars ($60.00) per calendar year. (Ord. 3202, 8-11-2014,
eff. 9-1-2014)
E. Testing Meters; Defective Meters:
1. Meter Tests: Upon request or complaint of the consumer or by the city, any water meter shall be
tested for accuracy. If, upon testing, the meter is found to be over three percent (3%) off in
accuracy, the meter shall be replaced or repaired at no cost to the consumer if less than one
inch (1") in diameter. If the meter is found to be three percent (3%) or less in accuracy, then the
consumer who made the request shall pay a testing fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a
meter one inch (1") or less. For meters one inch (1") or larger, the testing fee can range from two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) for the consumer if
accuracy is greater than three percent (3%). If accuracy is less than three percent (3%), the city
will bear the costs. If the meter is greater than one inch (1") in diameter, then the replacement
cost shall be borne by the consumer. (2013 Code)
2. Defective Meters: Where a meter has ceased to register, an estimate of the quantity of water
consumed will be based upon an average of the previous six (6) months' consumption and the
condition of service prevailing. (1977 Code § 13.64.040)
9-2-8: WATER SERVICE RATES:
A. Basis For Water Service Rate: The water service rate for the use of and for service supplied by the
water facilities of the city shall consist of a basic user rate, a debt service rate, and a capital
improvement rate.
1. Basic User Rate: The basic user rate is levied on all users to recover the operation,
maintenance plus replacement (OM&R) costs and shall be based on water usage as recorded
by water meters. The basic user rate shall be computed as follows:
a. Estimate the annual water volume.
b. Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the water facilities,
including a replacement fund for the year, for all works categories.
c. Compute costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons.
2. Debt Service Rate: The debt service rate is computed by apportioning the annual debt service
as a fixed charge per billing period.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 287/460
3. Capital Improvement Rate: The capital improvement rate is levied on users to provide for capital
improvements, extensions or reconstruction of the waterworks. The capital improvement rate is
computed by apportioning the annual amount to be accrued as a fixed rate per billing period.
4. Review Of Rates: The adequacy of the water service rate shall be reviewed, not less often than
annually, by a certified public accountant for the city in its annual audit report. The water service
rate shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in local capital costs or OM&R costs.
B. Measurement Of Flow:
1. The volume of flow used for computing basic user rates shall be the metered water consumption
read to the lowest even increments of one gallon.
2. If the person procures any part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public
waterworks system, the person shall install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type
approved by the city for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these
other sources.
3. Devices for measuring the volume of water may be required by the city if these volumes cannot
otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records.
4. Metering devices for determining the volume shall be installed, owned, and maintained by the
person. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is
canceled, without the consent of the city. (Ord. 2267, 6-10-2009)
C. Rates Established: Effective July 1, 2011, water usage rates of the city shall be as follows:
1. Water Usage Rates:
Gallons Of Water
Used Per Month Rate
Minimum up to 2,000 $8.60
Over minimum to 5,000, all usage $5.00 per 1,000 gallons
5,000 - 10,000 $4.60 per 1,000 gallons
10,000 - 100,000 $4.50 per 1,000 gallons
100,000 - 500,000 $4.40 per 1,000 gallons
500,000 - 1,500,000 $4.00 per 1,000 gallons
1,500,000 - 2,500,000 $3.75 per 1,000 gallons
2,500,000 - 4,000,000 $3.25 per 1,000 gallons
Over 4,000,000 $3.00 per 1,000 gallons
2. Debt Service Rate: A monthly debt service rate of two dollars thirty cents ($2.30) will be added
for all water customers within the city.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 288/460
3. Capital Improvement Rate: A monthly capital improvement rate of thirty cents ($0.30) will be
added for all water customers within the city.
4. Annual Increase: Water rates will be increased by three percent (3%) per fiscal year, excluding
debt service and capital improvement. (Ord. 2362, 6-13-2011)
D. Minimum Rate: A minimum rate of ten dollars ninety cents ($10.90) per month shall be applied to
all users whose water consumption does not exceed two thousand (2,000) gallons per month. This
minimum charge consists of eight dollars thirty cents ($8.30) for OM&R costs, two dollars thirty
cents ($2.30) for debt service costs and thirty cents ($0.30) for capital improvement costs.
E. Metered Water Required: All industrial, commercial and residential users of the water facilities shall
be metered.
F. Computation Of Water Service Rate: The water service rate shall be computed by the following
formula:
CW = CC + CD + CM + (Vu-X)CU
Where:
CW
=
Amount of water service rate ($) per billing period.
CC =
Capital improvement rate (subsection C3 of this section).
CD =
Debt service rate (subsection C2 of this section).
CM =
Minimum rate for operation, maintenance and replacement (subsection D of this
section).
Vu =
Water volume for the billing period.
X =
Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum rate (subsection D of this
section).
CU =
Basic user rate for operation, maintenance and replacement (subsection C1 of
this section).
G. Appeals: The method for computation of rates and service charges established for user charges in
this section shall be made available to a user within thirty (30) days of receipt of a written request
for such. Any disagreement over the method used or in the computations thereof shall be
remedied by mediation between user and water department within thirty (30) days after notification
of a formal written appeal outlining the discrepancies. (Ord. 2267, 6-10-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 289/460
9-2-9: BILLS FOR SERVICE; DELINQUENT PAYMENTS; REVENUES AND
ACCOUNTING:
A. Monthly Bills; Liability For Payment: Rates or charges for service of the premises shall be payable
monthly for services rendered. The occupant and the user of the service shall be jointly and
severally liable to pay for the service to such premises, and the service is furnished to the
premises by the city only upon the condition that the occupant and users of the services are jointly
and severally liable therefor to the city.
B. Rendition Of Bills; Due Date; Late Payment Penalty:
1. Bills for service shall be sent out by the city water department on the last working day of the
month succeeding the period for which the service is billed.
2. All bills are due and payable on the sixteenth day of the following month after being sent out. A
penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be added to all bills not paid by the sixteenth day after they
have been sent out.
C. Delinquent Payments; Discontinuance Of Service: If the charges for such services are not paid by
the twenty fifth of the month hereinabove mentioned after the rendition of the bill for such services,
such services shall be discontinued without further notice and shall not be reinstated until all claims
are settled.
D. Lien Provisions:
1. Lien Claim And Notice: Whenever a bill for service remains unpaid by the owner/user for ninety
(90) days for monthly service after it has been rendered, the city clerk shall file with the county
recorder of deeds a statement of claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the
premises served, the amount of unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this
amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill. (Ord. 2281, 8-24-
2009)
2. Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be sold for nonpayment
of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting
costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in
equity in the name of the city.
3. Suit For Foreclosure: The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings in the name of the city of Marion in any court having jurisdiction over such matters
against any property for which the bill has remained unpaid forty five (45) days in the case of a
monthly bill after it has been rendered. (Ord. 2267, 6-10-2009)
E. Revenues:
1. All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the water system shall be deposited in
the water account of the water fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the city
finance director-treasurer separate and apart from his private funds and separate and apart from
all other funds of the city finance director-treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of
the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the mayor
and council.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 290/460
2. The city finance director-treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the water system and all
other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered
to him and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the "water fund of the city
of Marion". Said finance director-treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the
manner provided by statute of the "revised cities and villages act", effective January 1942.
F. Accounting:
1. System Of Accounts: The city finance director-treasurer shall establish a proper system of
accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the water system, and at regular annual
intervals, he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to
show the receipts and disbursements of the water system. (Ord. 2267, 6-10-2009; amd. 2013
Code)
2. Annual Audit Report: In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report
shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the water facilities, including a
replacement cost. The financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the
following:
a. Flow data showing total gallons purchased from wholesale supplier for the current fiscal year.
b. Billing data to show total number of gallons billed per fiscal year.
c. Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
d. Capital improvement charges.
e. Number of users connected to the system.
f. Number of nonmetered users.
G. Access To Records: The IEPA or its authorized representative shall have access to any books,
documents, papers and records of the city which are applicable to the city system of user charges
for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure
compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant (loan agreement
and rules or any state loan).
H. Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each offense. (Ord. 2267, 6-10-2009)
9-2-10: BOILER SUPPLY:
Consumers having boilers connected with mains of the water department must have a check valve in
the supply pipe to the boiler and a vacuum valve in the steam line to prevent collapse in case the
water supply is interrupted for any reason. All consumers are cautioned against the danger of collapse
of boilers, since it is sometimes necessary to shut off the supply of water without notice. (1977 Code
§ 13.60.090)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 291/460
9-2-11: FLUSH VALVE OR DIRECT FLUSHING CLOSETS:
Flush valve or direct flushing closets should not be installed in premises where the service pipe
supplying such premises is connected to a two inch (2") or smaller main; nor should they be installed
on premises where the service pipe supplying such premises is connected to a main larger than two
inches (2") unless an elevated tank or a closed airtight pressure tank has been installed to supply
such closets. If the consumer insists on installing such fixtures in violation of this section, he shall do
so at his own risk, and in determining the size of the service pipe to be installed for such consumer,
the water department will consider only the average normal use of water, without any regard whatever
to peak demand required to operate the flush valve or direct flushing closets. (1977 Code § 13.60.100)
9-2-12: FIRE CONNECTIONS:
A. Service connection for water to be taken for the extinguishment of fire shall be made only upon
terms approved in writing by the superintendent of the water department and the city council.
These terms shall include pipe size, rates and any other information needed for a mutual
understanding agreement. (1977 Code § 13.60.050)
B. The following fee shall be collected monthly for fire connections to the water system of the city of
Marion:
Automatic sprinkler systems: Twenty seven dollars ($27.00). (Ord. 3202, 8-11-2014, eff. 9-1-2014)
C. A separate line (tap) shall be extended for fire line and potable water. Calculations shall be
submitted to determine the size of line prior to construction. (2013 Code)
9-2-13: USE OF HYDRANTS:
A. When it is necessary for any person to use a city fire hydrant as a source of water for any type
construction, or any other purpose, because no other source of water is available for use, such
person shall apply to the water department for a permit to use water from a city fire hydrant.
B. The person to whom a permit is issued shall be entitled to use water from a designated city fire
hydrant provided:
1. A fee in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) is paid to the water office
at the time a permit is applied for. If the water being used is for a project being paid for by the
city and the hydrant meter and backflow preventer are returned in good condition, one thousand
four hundred dollars ($1,400.00) shall be returned to the applicant.
2. The water department superintendent is promptly advised a permit has been applied for and the
name of the applicant.
3. No water will be withdrawn from a fire hydrant unless a hydrant meter and backflow prevention
have been put in place by city water department personnel.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 292/460
4. No person other than city water department personnel or Marion fire department personnel may
connect any apparatus or attach any wrench or tool to the operating stem or cap of an existing
city fire hydrant. This does not apply to new fire hydrants on proposed water main extensions
that are being used for flushing purposes and said hydrant has not been accepted by the city for
ownership.
5. Any person to whom the permit is issued shall be charged at the usual and customary rate for
the water used from the fire hydrant.
C. Any person using a city fire hydrant contrary to the provisions of this section may be fined not more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 3203, 8-14-2014)
9-2-14: EXTENSION OF MAINS:
A. State Approval Required: Where an extension of a main is necessary to serve a prospective
consumer or consumers, the water department will have plans and specifications drawn up in
accordance with the rules and regulations of the state department of public health pertaining to the
preparation and submission of plans and specifications for all public water supply improvements,
installations, changes, and additions. Said plans and specifications shall be submitted to the state
department of public health and written approval received from the department before work is
begun on the main extension. (1977 Code § 13.80.010)
B. Outside Of Subdivisions:
1. When a water main extension is necessary on city streets or alleys not in a new subdivision to
supply a consumer or consumers, the water department will extend the main, supplying all
materials and labor necessary, after a contract has been signed by the consumer or consumers,
and the water department superintendent. (1977 Code § 13.80.020; amd. 2013 Code)
2. Before the work is begun on the main extension, the ones desiring water service shall pay, in
advance at the water office, the estimated cost of extension. If the estimated cost is more or less
than the total cost, cash adjustment shall be made upon completion of the main extension.
3. The water department shall have the right to determine the size and kind of pipe, valves and
hydrants.
4. No cash allowance shall be given on any main unless the water department requires a larger
size pipe than necessary to serve consumers who will be presently served thereby, nor will there
be any reimbursement for taps for service.
5. The completed main will become the property of the city and, as such, will be maintained by the
water department. (1977 Code § 13.80.020)
C. Within Subdivisions:
1. Where water main extensions are for a new subdivision, the individual or individuals developing
said subdivision shall install and lay the mains, valves, hydrants and appurtenances which are
necessary to reach to and are within said subdivision at his or their expense. These mains,
valves, hydrants and appurtenances shall be laid and installed by or under the supervision of a
person or persons whose competence to supervise the work has been approved by the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 293/460
superintendent of the water department, and said superintendent shall have the right to inspect
the installations as they are made.
2. The water department shall have the right to determine the size and kind of pipe, valves,
hydrants and appurtenances to be used and the location of the water main, valves, hydrants and
appurtenances.
3. The water department shall have the right to refuse to connect any new water mains to existing
mains if material or manner of construction is not approved by the superintendent of the water
department.
4. No cash allowances will be given on any main unless the water department requires larger size
mains than necessary to serve the consumers who will be presently served thereby, and there
will be no reimbursements for taps for service.
5. Upon completion of the water main or mains, the city will accept said new main or mains for
maintenance if the main or mains have been approved by the superintendent of the water
department. (1977 Code § 13.80.030)
9-2-15: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Giving Away, Resale Of Water: Applications for water, when accepted by the water department,
shall cover only the premises and uses for which applied, and consumers are prohibited from
selling or giving away water or granting privileges to anyone to use water not specifically included
in the accepted application under penalty of a discontinuance of the supply and of a forfeiture of
water rent that may have been paid in advance. (1977 Code § 13.60.080)
B. Use Of Groundwater As Potable Water:
1. Definitions:
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited liability company,
corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other
legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns.
POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption including, but not
limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or preparing foods.
2. Use Prohibited: Except for such uses or methods in existence before the effective date hereof,
the use or attempt to use as a potable water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits
of the city by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other methods is hereby prohibited. This
prohibition applies to the city. (Ord. 1949, 5-3-2004)
3. Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this subsection shall be subject to a fine as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 1949, 5-3-2004; amd. 2013 Code)
9-2-16: INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE:
A. The water department shall make all reasonable efforts to eliminate interruption of service, and
when such interruption does occur, will endeavor to reestablish service with the shortest possible
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 294/460
delay. Whenever the service is interrupted for the purpose of working on the distribution system or
the pumping station equipment, all consumers affected by such interruption will be notified in
advance whenever it is possible to do so.
B. The water department shall in no event be held responsible for claims made against the
department by reason of the breaking of any mains or service pipes, or by reason of any other
interruption of the supply of water caused by the breaking of machinery or stoppage for necessary
repairs, and no person shall be entitled to damages, nor have any portion of a payment refunded
for any interruption of service which, in the opinion of the water department, may be deemed
necessary. (1977 Code § 13.76.080)
9-2-17: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE BY CONSUMER:
Any consumer desiring to discontinue, for any reason, the use of water to his premises must give
written notice at the water department office to that effect, whereupon the water will be shut off from
such premises at the curb stop or meter yoke. No charge for water rents will be stopped nor any
reduction made in the charge unless the water has been shut off by the water department, and such
stoppage or reduction in charge will be made only from date of receipt of the written notice from the
consumer, and then not for a period less than fifteen (15) days. (1977 Code § 13.76.060; amd. 2013
Code)
9-2-18: INSPECTIONS:
All premises receiving a supply of water and all service pipes, meters and fixtures, including any and
all fixtures within the premises, shall at all reasonable hours be subject to inspection by any duly
authorized employee of the water department. (1977 Code § 13.60.110)
9-2-19: VIOLATIONS; CANCELLATION OF SERVICE:
Application may be canceled or service discontinued by the water department after five (5) days'
written notice served at the premises supplied for violation of any of the water department rules and
regulations or any amendments that may be made thereto and especially for any of the following:
A. For misrepresentation in the application for water as to the property or fixtures to be supplied or the
use to be made of water.
B. For allowing any waste or misuse of water on account of improper line, fixtures or openings, and for
any failure on the part of the consumer to keep the same in suitable condition of repair so as to
prevent the waste of water.
C. For failure to pay water bills when due.
D. For any tampering with any meter or the seal thereof, or with any service pipe, curb or curb stop
cock or box owned by the water department, except in cases where it is necessary to shut off
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 295/460
water at the stop valve for repair between the stop valve owned by the water department and the
stop and waste valve owned by the property owner. All stop and waste valves on private property
shall be kept in good working condition. In the event a leak develops past a stop and waste valve
and the stop and waste valve cannot be shut off, and if the water department is called to shut off
the service at its stop valve, service will not be restored until the stop and waste valve has been
put in working condition and all leaks repaired.
E. For failure to adjust the service pipe to street grade as required by section 9-2-6 of this chapter.
F. For refusal to permit inspectors, meter reader, or other authorized employees of the water
department to enter the premises for the purposes specified in section 9-2-18 of this chapter.
G. For failure of the property owner or the occupant of the premises whose credit standing has been
impaired to make a cash deposit as provided in subsection 9-2-7D of this chapter.
H. For failure of a consumer to make a cash deposit or to give a satisfactory guarantee as provided in
subsection 9-2-7D of this chapter. (1977 Code § 13.60.130)
ARTICLE A. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
9-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
In the context of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed by this
section:
AGENCY: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
APPROVED: Backflow prevention devices or methods approved by the Research Foundation For
Cross Connection Control of the University Of Southern California (USC), the American Water Works
Association, the American National Standards Institute, and the American Society Of Sanitation
Engineers (ASSE) and certified by the National Sanitation Foundation.
ATMOSPHERIC VACUUM BREAKER: A backflow prevention device used as protection against cross
connection where the device is not subjected to back pressure due to pumps or any other conditions
which may cause back pressure. This device may never have a downstream shutoff valve or be
installed where it will be in continuous operation for more than twelve (12) hours.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the premises other than
the public water supply system and includes the water supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters
may include water from another purveyor's public water supply system, water from a source such as
wells, lakes, or streams, process fluids, or used water. These waters may be polluted or contaminated
or objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which the water purveyor does not have
control.
BACK SIPHONAGE: The flowing back of used, contaminated or polluted water due to a negative
gauge or subatmospheric pressure in that pipe.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 296/460
BACKFLOW: The flow of water, foreign liquids, gases or other substances back into the distribution
pipes of the potable water system.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method or type of construction intended to prevent
backflow into a potable water system in accordance with the standards of the Illinois plumbing code
and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
CITY: City of Marion.
COMMISSIONER: The city of Marion commissioner of the water department for the city of Marion, or
his designee.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the water by the presence of any substance to a
degree which could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2) otherwise separate
piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the other a substance of unknown or
questionable safety or quality, whereby there may be a flow from one system into the other.
Direct Cross Connection: A cross connection formed when a water system is physically joined to
a source of unknown or unsafe substance.
Indirect Cross Connection: A cross connection through which an unknown substance can be
forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe potable water system.
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICE INSPECTION (CCCDI): A plumber who holds an Illinois
plumbing license issued in accordance with 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 320/3(1) and who has
successfully completed both the written and performance examinations offered by the agency. These
examinations demonstrate an understanding of the principles of backflow and back siphonage and the
hazard presented to a potable water system; identifying locations which require installation of cross
connection control devices; identifying, locating, inspecting, testing, maintaining and repairing cross
connection control methods and devices in line, as located throughout each system which connects to
a community public water supply. These requirements are described in 35 Illinois administrative code
653.802(d)(1)(D) through (F).
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois department of public health.
DOUBLE CHECK DETECTOR ASSEMBLY: An assembly designed to prevent contamination of the
potable water system due to backflow from the fire protection system containing nontoxic substances.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly which is effective against backflow caused by
back pressure and back siphonage, which is used to protect the potable system from pollutants that
would not constitute an actual health hazard, but might be objectionable to the water supply system.
The double check valve assembly is used to isolate nonhealth hazards.
DRAIN: Any pipe that carries wastewater or waterborne wastes in a building drainage system.
FIXED PROPER AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between
the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the receptacle.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device, practice or substance in a water system or its operation
resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well being of consumers. The word "severe",
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 297/460
as used to qualify "health hazard", means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to
result in death or significant reduction in the quality of life.
INSPECTION: A plumbing inspection to carefully and critically examine all materials, fixtures, piping
and appurtenances, appliances and installations of a plumbing system to maintain compliance with
requirements of the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water not safe for consumption or personal or culinary use.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension of a plumbing system
by any person. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of
water for all purposes, including, without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of private
water supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to, within and about
any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble. Plumbing includes all
piping, from the discharge of pumping units to and including pressure tanks in water supply systems.
Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a building or buildings where
a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the
building sewer or private sewage disposal system five feet (5') beyond the foundation walls.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in
water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute, reduce or impair the usefulness of the water.
POTABLE WATER: Water for consumption, culinary and domestic purposes that meets all current
IEPA standards.
PROCESS FLUID(S): Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise
contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, pollution or
system hazard if introduced into the public or a consumer's potable water system. This includes, but is
not limited to:
A. Polluted or contaminated waters.
B. Process waters.
C. Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may have deteriorated in
sanitary quality.
D. Cooling waters.
E. Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or irrigation
systems.
F. Chemicals in solution or suspension.
G. Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other
processes, or for firefighting purposes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 298/460
PROPERTY OWNER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, tenant, occupant, official custodian or person in
control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system.
PROPERTY OWNER'S SYSTEM: Any water system located upon a customer's premises. A building
water plumbing system is considered to be a customer's water system.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: All mains, pipes, and structures through which water is obtained and
distributed to the public, including wells and well structures, intakes and cribs, pumping stations,
treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used
or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic use and which
serve at least fifteen (15) service connections or which regularly serve at least twenty five (25)
persons at least sixty (60) days per year. A public water supply is either a "community water supply" or
a "noncommunity water supply".
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device containing a
minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves, together with an automatically operated
pressure differential relief valve located between the two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE
standard 1013 and USC manual for RPZ devices. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal
flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of
leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall
operate between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly
closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly
located test cocks.
REDUCED PRESSURE ZONE (RPZ): A reduced pressure principle backflow preventer.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at the water main
through which water is supplied to the user.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system regarding the location
of all connections to the public water supply and must include the location, type and most recent
inspection and testing date of all cross connection control devices and methods located within that
customer's piping system. The survey must be in written form, and should not be an actual plumbing
inspection.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or degrading material,
not dangerous to health, may enter the public water supply system or a consumer's potable water
system.
USEPA: The United States environmental protection agency.
USFDA: The United States food and drug administration.
USED WATER: Any water supplied by a public water supply system to a consumer's water system
after it has passed through the service connection and is no longer under the control of the water
supply official custodian.
VACUUM: Any pressure less than that exerted by the atmosphere.
WATER PURVEYOR: The owner or official custodian of a public water system. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-2: COMPONENTS OF CITY WATER SYSTEM:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 299/460
The components of the city water system shall include the public water supply system and the
property owner's water system.
A. Public Water Supply: The public water supply system shall consist of the water source facilities and
the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities of the potable water system under the
control of the city water department up to the point where the property owner's water system
begins. This is generally at the meter.
B. Property Owner's Water Supply: The property owner's water system shall include all of the facilities
beyond the customer's side of the property line service connection (curb stop/shutoff) used to
convey water from the public water supply distribution system to the customer's points of use.
(Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-3: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
A. Connections between potable water systems and other systems, devices or equipment containing
water or other substances of unknown or questionable quality are prohibited except when and
where approved cross connection control devices or methods are installed, tested and maintained
to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis.
B. There shall be no facility, arrangement, device or connection by which an unsafe substance may
enter a potable water supply.
C. All property owners shall prevent backflow into the public water system by ensuring that:
1. All cross connections are eliminated or approved cross connection control devices are installed
by a CCCDI in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications for control of backflow and
back siphonage.
2. All cross connection control devices shall be inspected at least annually by a person approved
by the agency as a cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). The inspection of
mechanical devices shall include physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's
instructions and shall be at the property owner's expense. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-4: SURVEY, INVESTIGATION AND RECORDS CONTROL PROGRAM:
This section establishes an active cross connection survey, investigation and records control program
which includes, without limitation:
A. 1. A cross connection control survey of the distribution system shall be conducted by the city water
department superintendent, or his designee, at least every two (2) years. The purpose of this
survey is to compile and update an inventory of devices and to determine if potential or actual
cross connections exist.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 300/460
2. The survey shall consist of a pencil and paper collection of information conducted by telephone,
mail or personal visit to the owner, tenant, occupant or manager of a specific property. The
survey shall be completed, mailed or delivered back to the city water department office within
seven (7) days of receipt.
B. All premises of property owners shall, upon reasonable notice and at reasonable times, be open to
the water department superintendent for the inspection of the presence or absence of cross
connections and testing, repair and maintenance of cross connection control devices within the
premises of the property owners.
C. All property owners shall arrange on site inspection by a licensed plumber of water use practices
on the premises to determine whether there are actual or potential cross connections to the water
system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow into the private or public potable
water system. These surveys shall be at the property owner's expense. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-5: APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
A. Required: An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a
property owner's water system where, in the judgment of an agency certified CCCDI, an actual or
potential hazard to the public water supply system may exist, including, without limitation:
1. Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary supply is accepted as an
additional source by the city water department, and the source is approved by the Illinois
environmental protection agency;
2. Premises on which any substance is handled which can create an actual or potential hazard to
the public water supply system including, without limitation, premises having sources or systems
containing process fluids or waters originating from the public water supply system which are no
longer under the city water department sanitary control;
3. Premises having internal plumbing connections that, in the city water department's judgment,
are too intricate to determine whether or not cross connections exist;
4. Premises where, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is
impossible or impractical to make a complete cross connection survey; and
5. Premises where cross connections have been previously established or reestablished.
B. Installation: Unless an agency certified CCCDI determines that no actual or potential hazard to the
public water supply system exists, an approved backflow prevention device shall be installed in
accordance with the specifications of this article on each service line to a property owner's water
system serving, without limitation, facilities including:
1. Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, and nursing homes;
2. Laboratories;
3. Piers, docks and waterfront facilities;
4. Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or water pumping stations;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 301/460
5. Food or beverage processing and/or dispensing equipment;
6. Chemical plants;
7. Metal plating industries;
8. Petroleum processing or storage plants;
9. Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors;
10. Car washes; and
11. Microbreweries. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-6: LEVEL OF PROTECTION:
Based on the degree of hazard to the water system, an appropriate level of protection shall be
required, including, without limitation:
A. An approved fixed proper air gap separation shall be installed where the public water supply
system may be contaminated with substances that could cause a severe health hazard.
B. An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow
prevention device shall be installed where the public water supply system may be contaminated
with a substance that could cause a system or health hazard.
C. An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved double detector check valve assembly
backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public water supply system may be
polluted with substances that could cause a pollution hazard not dangerous to health. (Ord. 1719,
3-1-1999)
9-2A-7: FIRE SAFETY SYSTEMS:
A. Fire safety systems shall be equipped with a double detector check valve assembly or RPZ valve
located at the point of connection between the fire safety system and the water supply line to
protect the water supply against backflow and back siphonage.
B. A fixed proper air gap with a break tank or other storage vessel or a reduced pressure principle
backflow preventer shall be installed at the point of connection between the fire safety system and
the water supply service line to protect the water supply against backflow and back siphonage
when the fire safety system contains additives such as antifreeze, fire retardant or other chemicals.
The RPZ assembly may be located at the point of connection to the section of the system
containing such additives when the connection to the water supply is protected by a double
detector valve assembly. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
9-2A-8: APPROVED CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 302/460
A. Approved Devices Required:
1. Only approved cross connection control devices found to be in compliance with applicable
industry specifications shall meet the requirements of this article. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999; amd.
2013 Code)
2. In addition to the requirements contained in this section, only cross connection control devices
which meet the Illinois plumbing code for cross connection control devices shall be approved for
use.
B. Types Of Approved Devices: Approved cross connection control devices include:
1. A fixed proper air gap which shall be used whenever technically possible.
2. Atmospheric vacuum breakers which may be installed subject to the following conditions:
a. An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall not be installed where back pressure may occur;
b. An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall be installed at the highest point in the water line and
after the last control valve before the point of discharge and a minimum of six inches (6")
above the flood level rim of the receptacle;
c. An atmospheric vacuum breaker shall not be used for installations where the substance in the
container receiving water is lethal or toxic. Examples of acceptable installations include,
without limitation:
(1) Surface wash piping for a gravity filter;
(2) Solution tanks of gravimetric dry chemical feeders;
(3) Outlets with hose attachments; or
(4) Receptacles with a low level inlet where the substance contained is nontoxic such as food
or beverages.
3. Reduced pressure principle backflow preventers (RPZ) may be installed in accordance with the
specifications of this article, subject to the following conditions:
a. Installation:
(1) Units shall be accessible for maintenance and testing;
(2) Minimum clearances recommended by the manufacturer shall be used;
(3) Relief ports shall not be plugged. A drain of sufficient size to accommodate the RPZ water
discharge rate of flow shall be provided and shall remain free flowing under all conditions;
(4) A collection system with an air gap under the relief port drain shall be installed with ceiling
level units; and
(5) No reduction shall be made in the size of the relief port drain.
b. Bypasses: A second backflow preventer shall be installed parallel to the first if there is only
one service line and the water service cannot be interrupted. Bypass lines without approved
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 303/460
backflow preventers shall not be installed.
c. Reduced Pressure Principle Backflow Preventers: Reduced pressure principle backflow
preventers shall be used for installations where a fixed proper air gap is not possible,
including, without limitation:
(1) The water line used to provide makeup water for chemical feeders in a water treatment
plant;
(2) Receptacles with a low level inlet where the contents are nontoxic such as food or
beverages; and
(3) Receptacles or vessels which can subject the water supply line to back pressure.
d. Water Service Lines: Water service lines which connect a community water supply to
industrial or commercial establishments shall include either a reduced pressure principle
backflow preventer or a fixed proper air gap with repumping if those establishments constitute
a hazard to the water supply due to the nature of chemicals or other material handled within
the facility. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
C. Installation: Installation of approved devices shall be made in accordance with 35 Illinois
administrative code 653.802 and only as specified by the Research Foundation For Cross
Connection Control of the University Of Southern California or applicable industry specifications.
(Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
D. Maintenance: Maintenance as recommended by the manufacturer of the device shall be performed.
The manufacturer's maintenance manual shall be available on the premises. (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-9: INSTANTANEOUS WATER HEATERS AND WATER STORAGE HEATERS:
Instantaneous water heaters and water storage heaters using shell and tube design hot water boilerfire
heat exchangers shall be acceptable for heating water for domestic use under the following
conditions:
A. Chemical Additives:
1. Chemical additives to control corrosion and scale of the hot water boiler system shall not contain
toxic chemicals (e.g., chromate or nitrite based inhibitors).
2. Chemicals approved by the USEPA or USFDA which will not break down to harmful substances
in the system may be applied for scale and corrosion control in public water supplies (e.g., food
grade caustic soda, sodium silicate, sodium polyphosphate).
3. The addition of sodium sulfite as an oxygen scavenger in hot water boilers is acceptable when
approved double check valves in compliance with 35 Illinois administrative code 653.801(d) are
installed.
B. Double Check Valve Assembly:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 304/460
1. A double check valve assembly in compliance with 35 Illinois administrative code 653.801(d)
shall be installed in the cold water inlet piping of the heat exchanger;
2. The unit shall be tested annually and required service performed within fifteen (15) days; and
3. A maintenance log shall be maintained and a copy submitted to the city water department office
within seven (7) days of inspection, repair, testing or change to include information specified in
35 Illinois administrative code 653.802(e)(4). (Ord. 1719, 3-1-1999)
9-2A-10: RESPONSIBILITY OF PROPERTY OWNER, TENANT OR OCCUPANT:
A. The property owner, tenant or occupant of any premises where backflow prevention devices
required by this article are installed shall have all devices inspected, tested, maintained and
