11-13-6: DESIGN OF LOADING FACILITIES:
If provided, all off street loading facilities shall conform to the following minimum standards:
A. Size Of Space: Every off street loading space shall be at least twelve feet (12') wide and sufficiently
long to accommodate the type of vehicle expected to use the space. In no case shall a vehicle
being loaded or unloaded overhang into the public right of way.
B. Accessway: Every off street loading space shall have a safe means of vehicular access to a street
or alley. Such accessway shall be at least twelve feet (12') wide.
C. Surfacing: Every off street loading area shall be improved with a compacted stone base at least
seven inches (7") thick. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
Chapter 14
NONCONFORMITIES
11-14-1: PURPOSE:
The requirements imposed by this title are designed to guide the use of land by encouraging the
development of structures and uses that are compatible with the predominant character of each of the
various districts. Lots, structures, and uses of land or structures that do not conform to the
requirements of the district in which they are located tend to impede appropriate development. For
example, nonconformities are frequently responsible for heavy traffic on residential streets, the
overtaxing of parking facilities, the creation of nuisances, and/or the lowering of property values. The
regulations of this chapter are intended to alleviate such existing/potential problems by encouraging
the gradual elimination of nonconformities. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-2: NONCONFORMING LOTS:
A. Any vacant lot that does not conform to one or more of the lot size (area, dimensions) requirements
of the district in which it is located may, nonetheless, be developed for any use permitted in that
district if such vacant lot:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 436/460
1. Was recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds prior to the effective date hereof; and
2. Is at least thirty feet (30') wide.
B. If two (2) or more lots or combinations of lots with continuous street frontage were of record and in
common ownership on the effective date hereof, and if one or more of those lots does not meet the
minimum lot width, depth, or area requirements of the district in which it is located, the land
involved shall be considered an undivided parcel. No portion of any such parcel shall be developed
(used) except in compliance with this title, nor shall any such parcel be divided so as to create a lot
that does not meet the requirements of this title. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-3: NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES:
Any otherwise lawful structure which exists on the effective date hereof but which could not be erected
under the terms of this title because of requirements/restrictions concerning lot size, height, setbacks,
or other characteristics of the structure or its location on the lot may lawfully remain, subject to the
following provisions:
A. Maintenance: A nonconforming structure may be maintained by ordinary repairs.
B. Enlargement, Alterations: A nonconforming structure may be enlarged and/or altered; provided,
that:
1. Such enlargement and/or alteration is confined within the lot lines of the property in question as
such lot lines existed on the effective date hereof; and
2. Such enlargement and/or alteration does not increase or worsen the nonconforming
characteristics of the structure.
C. Reconstruction:
1. A nonconforming structure that is damaged or destroyed may be rebuilt; provided, that:
a. Reconstruction commences within one year from the date of damage/destruction and is
diligently pursued to completion; and
b. The structure, when reconstructed, will not be more nonconforming than it had been.
2. If reconstruction does not commence within one year or is not diligently pursued to completion,
as determined by the administrator, the damaged structure shall be considered abandoned.
Reconstruction at that point shall be allowed only if the structure will be rebuilt in conformity with
the provisions of this title which are applicable to new structures.
D. Relocation: A nonconforming structure shall not be moved to another lot unless, after relocation, it
will conform to all the regulations of the district where it will be situated. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff.
6-1-1987)
11-14-4: NONCONFORMING USES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 437/460
Any otherwise lawful use existing on the effective date hereof that would not be permitted under the
terms of this title may lawfully continue, subject to the following provisions:
A. Expansion/Intensification:
1. A nonconforming use which does not occupy a structure (such as a plant nursery) may be
expanded/intensified, but only within the confines of the lot lines as such lot lines existed on the
effective date hereof.
2. A nonconforming use which occupies a structure may be expanded or intensified, but only within
that structure and/or within any conforming addition to said structure. (For rules concerning
expansion of nonconforming structures, see subsection 11-14-3B of this chapter.)
B. Reestablishment: A nonconforming use which is destroyed or damaged may be reestablished.
However, if the owner of said damaged/destroyed use proposes to expand, relocate, or change it,
then the other pertinent provisions of this section shall control. Moreover, if no significant steps
have been taken to reestablish the use within one year from the date the damage occurred, then
the use shall be considered abandoned and subject to the provisions of subsection E of this
section.
C. Relocation: A nonconforming use shall not be moved, in whole or in part, unless, upon relocation, it
will conform to all pertinent regulations of the district in which it will be relocated.
D. Change Of Use: A nonconforming use may continue, but shall not be changed except to a use that
is permitted under the applicable district regulations.
E. Discontinuance: When a nonconforming use is discontinued for a period of twelve (12) months, it
shall not thereafter be resumed. Any subsequent use shall conform to the uses permitted in the
applicable zone district. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-5: EXISTING PERMITS:
The regulations of this chapter shall not affect the terms of any permit issued prior to the effective date
hereof or any pertinent amendment hereto; provided, that the work authorized by such permit is
completed within a reasonable time. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
Title 12
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL SUBDIVISION PROVISIONS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 438/460
12-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this title, certain terms used in this title are defined as set forth in this section.
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The city code enforcement officer.
IMPROVEMENTS: Water and sanitary sewer systems, streets and alleys, storm sewers and drainage
systems.
LARGE TRACT SUBDIVISION: The division of a tract or parcel of land into two (2), three (3), or four
(4) lots, plots, sites, or other divisions of land, or the consolidation of the same number of parcels into
a lesser number, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building
development when:
A. The smallest resulting parcel is ten (10) acres or more;
B. No new street construction is required; and
C. No new easement of access is required.
LOT: A parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership on building development, whether immediate
or future. A lot shall have frontage on a public street.
PLAN COMMISSION: The city plan commission.
PROJECT INSPECTOR: The inspector present during construction of improvements.
STREET: Any street intended to serve or provide access to the properties in the subdivision.
SUBDIVISION: The division of a tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots, plots, sites, or other
divisions of land, or the consolidation of parcels, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of
transfer of ownership or building development; provided, however, that this definition shall not include
bona fide large tract subdivisions which result in parcels of ten (10) acres or more not involving any
new street construction or easement of access. (1977 Code §§ 16.08.010 - 16.08.080; amd. Ord.
1162, 7-14-1987; 2013 Code)
12-1-2: JURISDICTION:
The rules and regulations governing plats and subdivisions of land contained in this title shall apply to
that land located within the corporate limits of the city and to land located within one and one-half
(11/2) miles of its corporate limits. (1977 Code § 16.04.010)
12-1-3: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
A. Within the territorial limits of this title, no person, firm or corporation shall change, resubdivide, or
rearrange the boundary or division line of any lot or parcel of land, or divide the same into building
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 439/460
lots for the purpose of sale, or for lease for a period of more than five (5) years, without meeting
the requirements of this title. Nor shall any such person, firm or corporation begin with any
construction work in a proposed subdivision, including grading, without complying with the
provisions of this title and before obtaining the approval of the plat of the proposed subdivision as
provided in this title. (1977 Code § 16.04.020)
B. Unless the plat is so approved, no subdivision shall be entitled to record in the county recorder's
office, nor have any validity; the code enforcement officer will not issue building or repair permits
for any structure on a lot in any such subdivision; and the city will not permit any public
improvements or allow any city service to be extended to any such subdivision. (1977 Code
§ 16.04.020; amd. 2013 Code)
12-1-4: VARIANCES:
The general principles of design and minimum requirements for the laying out of subdivisions, set forth
in chapter 4 of this title, may be varied in a particular case where the subdivider can show that, by
reason of exceptional topographic or other physical conditions, strict compliance with any requirement
of this title could cause practical difficulty or exceptional and undue hardship. Such variation shall be
made by the city council only upon receiving from the plan commission a recommendation that such
variation be allowed. Before making such recommendation, the plan commission must find that such
relief may be granted without detriment to the public good and without impairing the intent and
purpose of this title or the desirable general development of the neighborhood and community. (1977
Code § 16.24.010; amd. 2013 Code)
12-1-5: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this title is declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of proper jurisdiction, that
decision shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-1-6: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
Except as may be provided otherwise by statute or ordinance, no official, city council member, agent,
commission or board appointee, or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any
damage that may occur to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the
discharge of duties under this title. Any such person made a party to a civil action, civil rights or
constitutional rights damage action, or antitrust action by reason of the discharge of said duties shall
be held harmless and indemnified by the city for all damages and attorney fees incurred; provided,
that: a) the person makes a timely disclosure of the litigation or threatened litigation to the city; and b)
the person authorizes the city to provide primary representation through the city attorney in such
litigation or threatened litigation and cooperates with the city in the primary presentation. The city will
not indemnify such person for punitive damages assessed against the person nor pay attorney fees
incurred by the person for counsel not retained by the city. Said indemnification shall be against all
judgments, fines, amounts paid in settlements, and reasonable expenses incurred resulting from any
such action or proceeding, or any appeal, to the fullest amount permitted by the laws of the state of
Illinois. The foregoing statement of indemnification is deemed to be a contract between the city and
each city official, city council member, agent, commission or board appointee, or employee with
explicit or implied responsibilities under the provisions of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 440/460
12-1-7: PENALTY:
For the violation of any of the provisions of this title, the one so violating shall, upon conviction, be
fined in any amount up to and including the amount provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code
§ 16.16.080; amd. 2013 Code)
Chapter 2
SUBDIVISION PLAT; APPROVAL PROCEDURE
12-2-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
In planning and developing a subdivision, the general principles and requirements set forth in chapter
4 of this title shall be observed, and in every case, the procedure set forth in this chapter shall be
followed. (1977 Code § 16.12.010)
12-2-2: PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL:
A. Application For Approval; Fee:
1. The subdivider shall submit to the plan commission application for approval of the plat of the
proposed subdivision which shall have attached thereto two (2) copies of the plat and two (2)
copies of the construction plans, if any, for public improvements or improvements for future
dedication to the city to be installed conforming with the requirements set forth in chapter 3 of
this title. The application shall be filed with the plan commission at least two (2) weeks prior to a
meeting thereof. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
2. At the time of filing an application for approval, the subdivider shall pay to the city clerk a fee of
one dollar ($1.00) for each lot in the subdivision, which shall be deposited into the city general
fund to be used to defray the expenses for the administration of this title. (1977 Code
§ 16.12.110; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Code Enforcement Officer Review: The commission chair, immediately upon receipt of such
application, shall deliver one copy of the application to the code enforcement officer who will make
an on site inspection of the area to be subdivided, review the application, plat and plans, and
report his recommendations and advice within ten (10) days to the plan commission. (1977 Code
§ 16.12.030; amd. 2013 Code)
C. Plan Commission Decision: The plan commission, upon receipt of the code enforcement officer's
report, shall approve or disapprove the application within two (2) weeks.
D. City Council Approval: If the application is approved by the commission, the commission will
recommend approval of the plat by the city council at its next meeting following the action of the
commission. Approval of the plat by the city council will authorize the subdivider to proceed with
the proposed improvements in accordance with the general standards set forth in chapter 3 of this
title, unless waived by the city council. The commission will return one copy of the plat and plans to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 441/460
the subdivider with the date of approval. One copy will be kept by the commission for the use of
the code enforcement officer. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013 Code)
E. Disapproval: If the application is disapproved by the commission, the subdivider must be furnished
with a letter stating the reason for disapproval and in what manner the plat and/or plans fail to
conform with this chapter or other city ordinances or regulations. Such letters shall be given to the
subdivider within the two (2) week period mentioned in subsection A1 of this section. (1977 Code
§ 16.12.060)
12-2-3: IMPROVEMENTS:
A. Permit Or Security Required For Streets And Sanitary Improvements: The subdivider, after
approval of the application, may: 1) secure from the proper city authorities the necessary permits
to proceed with the street and sanitary improvements, or, in lieu of this, 2) post with the
commission a surety bond, or other security, in the form prescribed by the city council, sufficient to
cover the full cost of improvements based upon estimates submitted to and approved by the code
enforcement officer, unless waived by the city council. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013 Code)
B. Inspection Of Improvements; Issuance Of Certificate: Upon the satisfactory installation of
improvements in accordance with this title, the code enforcement officer will make a twofold
certificate showing that the technical details of the plat itself have been checked and found
satisfactory and all required improvements have been satisfactorily completed, or, in lieu thereof, a
surety bond has been posted with the commission assuring their installation. (1977 Code
§ 16.12.080; amd. 2013 Code)
C. City Council Approval: When the improvements have been certified as provided in subsection B of
this section, or when a surety bond or other security has been provided or waived as so specified
in subsection A of this section, the commission will transmit the plat to the city council for approval.
Such plat shall bear an official notation reading:
Recommended for approval and acceptance this day of . (Signed) Chair of the Plan
Commission.
Thereupon, the city council may approve and accept the plat. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013
Code)
D. Maintenance Bond Or Security Required: The subdivider shall post a maintenance bond or other
security acceptable to the city council covering ten percent (10%) of the cost of any improvement
to be accepted for maintenance by the city unless waived by the city council. Such bond shall be
held by the city clerk and shall become effective upon acceptance of the plat by the city, unless
otherwise stipulated. Maintenance bonds shall run for one year on such improvements. (Ord. 1162,
7-14-1987)
12-2-4: REQUIRED INFORMATION ON PLAT:
The plat shall be drawn at the scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') or less, and shall
clearly show the following features and information:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 442/460
A. Legal description of the property, including reference to the section, township and range; section
lines and corners; quarter section lines.
B. Names and addresses of the owner or owners of record, the subdivider, and of the registered
Illinois land surveyor who prepared the plat.
C. The proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate or closely approximate the name
of any other subdivision in the city or environs.
D. Names and locations of adjoining subdivisions.
E. Lots numbered in numerical order, and blocks also numbered in numerical order; the proposed lots
to have dimensions indicated.
F. The layout, proposed names and widths of proposed streets and alleys, and the width of
easements.
G. Proposed front yard setback or other setback lines.
H. All parcels of land intended to be dedicated or reserved for public use, or to be reserved in the
deeds for the common use of property owners in the subdivision, with the purpose, conditions, or
limitations of such dedication or reservation indicated.
I. Existing sewers, water mains, culverts, and other underground structures within the tract and
immediately adjacent thereto, with the pipe sizes and grades indicated.
J. North point, scale and date.
K. The accurate location and material of all permanent reference monuments. There shall be located
at each of the extreme corners of the subdivision a concrete cylinder or rectangular prism not less
than four inches (4") in diameter or square, and twenty four inches (24") long. There shall be
located at all street corners, at all points where street lines intersect the plat boundary lines, steel
rods not less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in diameter and twenty four inches (24") long. At all lot
corners, there shall be one-half inch (1/2") square iron pins, twenty four inches (24") in length.
L. Dedication.
M. Certification by the registered Illinois land surveyor who prepared the plat to the effect that the plat
represents a survey made by him, that all monuments indicated thereon actually exist, and that
their location, size and material are correctly shown.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 443/460
N. Other certificates required by law, including certificate of title showing ownership of the tract of land
included in the subdivision; also certificate from the county clerk showing that all taxes have been
paid. (1977 Code § 16.20.010)
Chapter 3
IMPROVEMENTS
12-3-1: REQUIRED; REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF PLANS:
A. Minimum improvements must be installed, unless a surety bond is filed, prior to approval and
acceptance of the plat, in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. (1977 Code
§§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020)
B. The code enforcement officer shall review the construction plans for improvements with the
superintendents of the city water, sewer and street departments upon the delivery of such plans to
him from the plan commission. (1977 Code §§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020; amd. 2013 Code)
C. Such plans shall be revised by the subdivider as may be necessary to comply with this chapter and
all other city ordinances. Failure to make such revisions will be grounds for nonapproval and
nonacceptance of the plat. (1977 Code §§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020)
12-3-2: CONSTRUCTION AND COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS GENERALLY:
A. All the improvements required by this chapter shall be constructed or installed in accordance with
the plans submitted to and approved by the plan commission.
B. None of the improvements will be installed or constructed unless there is an inspector present on
the project. Such project inspector shall have been previously approved by the superintendent of
the city department under whose jurisdiction the particular improvement falls. The expenses of the
project inspector shall be borne by the subdivider. (1977 Code § 16.16.030)
C. All such improvements shall be completed prior to approval and acceptance of the plat; or in lieu of
the completing the required improvements, the subdivider must furnish the plan commission with a
surety bond, sufficient to cover the cost of any or all of the required improvements not then
completed, based upon an estimate submitted to and approved by the code enforcement officer,
thereby to secure the construction or installation of such improvements within one year after the
acceptance of the plat. (1977 Code § 16.16.030; amd. 2013 Code)
D. When the construction or installation of the improvements has been completed, the subdivider shall
file an affidavit with the commission certifying that such improvements have been completed
without variation from the plans previously approved. (1977 Code § 16.16.030)
12-3-3: STREETS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 444/460
A. Streets shall be planned and constructed taking into account the best possible manner of disposal
of surface water and the location of water mains and sanitary sewers.
B. All streets shall have an improved surface at least twenty seven feet (27') in width.
C. The streets shall have a crushed rock or stone base of six inches (6") when compacted for streets
with asphalt surface.
D. There shall be curb and gutter on each side of the street in compliance with subsection 8-1-1A4 of
this code. (1977 Code § 16.16.040; amd. 2013 Code)
12-3-4: WATER SUPPLY:
A. Every subdivision shall be provided with a complete water distribution system adequate to serve
the area being platted, including appropriately spaced fire hydrants, with steam nozzles. The
spacing of the hydrants is to be approved by the city fire chief, and the entire water system shall be
designed to meet the approval of the Illinois department of public health and the superintendent of
the city water department.
B. All water mains in the distribution system shall be flushed and sterilized in the presence of the
project inspector, and they shall not be put into use until approved for use by the Illinois
department of public health.
C. All water mains in the distribution system shall be subjected to a pressure test whereby the mains
will be under ordinary main pressure plus fifty (50) pounds per square inch for a period of eight (8)
hours without interruption. The mains must maintain such pressure for such period, the prescribed
allowance for leakage being permitted, before the mains will be considered as completed.
D. No water shall be used from the city system for flushing, sterilizing or testing without prior approval
of the superintendent of the city water department. (1977 Code § 16.16.050)
12-3-5: SEWER SYSTEM:
A. Required: In every subdivision, provision shall be made for the satisfactory disposal of sanitary
sewage. (1977 Code § 16.16.060)
B. Use Of City Sanitary Sewer System:
1. Where a city sanitary sewer main is accessible, the subdivision shall be provided with a
complete sanitary sewage collection system connected to such sewer main. Such collection
system shall be adequate in size to serve the area platted and/or the most advantages for future
development of adjacent tracts. The entire system, including layout, construction plans, profiles
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 445/460
and specifications, shall be designed to meet the approval, first, of the superintendent of the city
sewer department, and second, the environmental protection agency.
2. All sewer mains in the collection system shall be subjected to either infiltration or exfiltration
leakage tests for an uninterrupted period of twenty four (24) hours in the presence of the project
inspector. The prescribed allowance for leakage must be met before the mains will be
considered complete. The system shall not be put into use until approved for use by the
superintendent of the city sewer department and the environmental protection agency. (1977
Code § 16.16.060; amd. 2013 Code)
3. The sewer collection system shall include a connection for each lot, extended from the main
sewer to the lot line. The superintendent of the city sewer department shall be furnished with a
complete and accurate record, by measurement, of the location of the point of intersection of the
extended lot connection and the lot line, for a permanent record. (1977 Code § 16.16.060)
C. Use Of Private System: Where a city sanitary sewer main is not accessible, proper provision shall
be made for the collection and disposal of sanitary wastes, subject to the approval of the
environmental protection agency, the Franklin and Williamson bi-county health department and the
superintendent of the city sewer department. (1977 Code § 16.16.060; amd. 2013 Code)
12-3-6: UTILITIES:
Poles or underground conduits for electric lights, telephone lines or other utilities must be placed in
easements provided along rear or side lot lines, wherever this is practicable. (1977 Code § 16.16.070)
12-3-7: MONUMENTS:
Monuments must be placed in accordance with the requirements of section 12-2-4 of this title. (1977
Code § 16.16.070)
Chapter 4
DESIGN STANDARDS
12-4-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
In laying out a subdivision, the subdivider must comply with the general principles and requirements
set forth in this chapter. (1977 Code § 16.28.010)
12-4-2: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
The street layout of the subdivision must, in general, conform with the most advantageous
development of adjoining areas and the entire neighborhood. The criteria for such layout shall be as
follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 446/460
A. Where appropriate to the design, proposed streets shall be continuous and in alignment with
existing planned or platted streets with which they connect. (1977 Code § 16.28.020)
B. Proposed streets shall extend to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented
by topography or other physical conditions, or unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, such
extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with
existing layouts for the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. Dead end
streets (courts) of reasonable length may be approved where topography necessitates or where
they are appropriate for the type of development contemplated. (1977 Code § 16.28.020; amd.
2013 Code)
C. Proposed streets should intersect one another as nearly at right angles as topography and other
limiting factors of good design permit. Not more than a ten percent (10%) deviation from a right
angle will be allowed without prior written permission of the plan commission.
D. Wherever there exists, adjoining the tract to be subdivided, a dedicated or platted and recorded half
width street or alley, the other half width shall be platted.
E. Alleys shall be platted in the rear of all lots to be used for business and in the rear of residential lots
fronting on primary streets as a means of safe access to such lots. (1977 Code § 16.28.020)
12-4-3: BLOCKS:
A. Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two (2) tiers of lots of appropriate depth, unless, in
the opinion of the plan commission, prevented by exceptional topography or other physical
conditions.
B. In any block over nine hundred feet (900') in length, the plan commission shall require that a
crosswalk or pedestrianway not less than ten feet (10') wide be provided near the center and
entirely across such block. (1977 Code § 16.28.020; amd. 2013 Code)
12-4-4: EASEMENTS:
A. Right Of Way Easements:
1. Streets: The right of way for all streets shall be forty feet (40'). All dead end streets shall
terminate in a circular runaround having a minimum right of way diameter of one hundred feet
(100'). (1977 Code § 16.28.030; amd. 2013 Code)
2. Alleys And Service Drives: The right of way for alleys and service drives shall be twenty feet
(20').
B. Utilities Easements: Utilities easements, where required, shall be at least fifteen feet (15') wide
centered on rear or side lot lines. (1977 Code § 16.28.030)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 447/460
12-4-5: LOTS:
A. The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the proposed
subdivision and for the type of development contemplated, the zoning ordinance requirements to
be complied with in all respects.
B. Excessive depth in relation to width ordinarily shall be avoided.
C. Every lot must abut upon a street.
D. Lots for residence purposes must be at least sixty feet (60') wide at the building setback line.
E. Corner lots for residential use shall be ordinarily platted wider than interior lots.
F. Double frontage lots and reversed frontage lots will be ordinarily avoided.
G. Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles to the right of way line of the street on which the
lot fronts. Not more than a ten percent (10%) deviation from a right angle will be allowed without
prior written permission of the plan commission. (1977 Code § 16.28.040)
Chapter 5
LARGE TRACT SUBDIVISIONS
12-5-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
Within the territorial limits of this title, a parcel or tract of land may be divided into two (2), three (3), or
four (4) lots, plots, sites or other divisions of land, or consolidation of the same number of parcels into
a lesser number, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building
development when: a) the smallest resulting parcel is ten (10) acres or more; b) no new street
construction is required; and c) no new easement of access is required. Large tract subdivisions are
subject to the procedures and standards set forth in this chapter and are exempt from the procedures
and standards for subdivisions as established in other sections of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-5-2: APPROVAL PROCEDURE:
A. Authority Of Code Enforcement Officer: The code enforcement officer is authorized to receive
applications for large tract subdivisions, review said applications, and approve large tract
subdivisions for recording.
B. Application For Subdivision; Fee: Applications for large tract subdivisions will be filed with the code
enforcement officer on a prescribed form. The fee for said filing shall be twenty five dollars
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 448/460
($25.00). The application will include a legal description of the proposed subdivision with reference
provisions to sections, townships and range. A scaled sketch of the proposed subdivision shall
accompany the application that contains sufficient information for the code enforcement officer to
determine: 1) that the smallest resulting parcel is ten (10) acres or more; 2) that no new easement
of access will be required; 3) that no new street construction will be necessary; and 4) that the
resulting subdivision will comply with the current provisions of title 11 of this code.
C. Review And Approval Of Application:
1. If the code enforcement officer determines it appropriate and necessary to the review of the
application, the services of a registered civil engineer may be secured, at the expense of the
subdivider, to assist in the verification of the standards stated above.
2. Upon determination of the application's compliance with the provisions of this title, the code
enforcement officer may approve the application and authorize recording without further action
by the city.
3. All review functions of the code enforcement officer pursuant to this chapter shall be conducted
and concluded within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of the receipt of the application.
D. Request For Additional Information: Should the code enforcement officer determine that insufficient
information exists to make a final decision on the application, a formal request for the additional
information will be forwarded to the applicant. The review period may be extended an additional
fifteen (15) calendar days upon request of additional information by the code enforcement officer.
E. Denial Of Application; Appeals: Incomplete applications and/or applications that fail to meet all of
the qualifications for a large tract subdivision will be denied by the code enforcement officer.
Applicants may appeal any decision of the code enforcement officer pursuant to this chapter to the
city council. The city council will hear and decide the appeal at the next meeting. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-
1987; amd. 2013 Code)
12-5-3: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
No penalties shall be imposed for violation of this chapter; except, that the city council may seek
injunctive relief to stop or prevent violations within the jurisdictional boundaries of this title. (Ord. 1162,
7-14-1987)
Title 13
FLOOD CONTROL
Chapter 1
DEVELOPMENT IN FLOOD HAZARD AREAS
13-1-1: STATUTE AUTHORITY; PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 449/460
This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to the city by 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2, in order to accomplish the following
purposes: (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
A. To prevent unwise development from increasing the flood or drainage hazards to others;
B. To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood damage;
C. To protect human life and health from the hazards of flooding;
D. To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control projects, repairs to flood damaged public
facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
E. To maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the potential for creating flood
blight areas;
F. To make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in the city; and
G. To provide for the orderly growth and development pursuant to the city's comprehensive plan of an
environment that is especially sensitive to changes from human activity. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-2: PROVISIONS FOR ACCOMPLISHING PURPOSE:
All new development proposals in the special flood hazard areas shall be reviewed and approved by
the code enforcement officer. The code enforcement officer's review is to ensure the following: (Ord.
1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
A. New development will not change the flow of flood or other surface drainage waters so that other
properties become more susceptible to damage;
B. New development will not create special hazards or nuisances when flooded; and
C. New buildings and major improvements to existing buildings will not be subject to damage by the
base flood. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
BASE FLOOD: The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or exceeded in any
given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood. The base flood elevation at any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 450/460
location is defined in section 13-1-4 of this chapter.
BUILDING: A structure that is principally aboveground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term
includes a gas or liquid storage tank in order that such tanks will be constructed to the same flood
damage protection standards. The term includes a mobile home or prefabricated building which is
affixed on a permanent site and connected to the required utilities. The term does not include
recreational vehicles or travel trailers.
DEVELOPMENT: A. Any manmade change to real estate, including:
1. Construction, reconstruction, or placement of a building or an addition to a building valued at
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);
2. Installing a mobile home on a site or preparing a site for a mobile home;
3. Drilling, mining, installing utilities or facilities, construction of roads, bridges or similar projects
valued at more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);
4. Construction or erection of levees, walls, or fences;
5. Filling, dredging, grading, excavating, or other nonagricultural alterations of the ground
surface;
6. Storage of materials; or
7. Any other activity that might change the direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface waters.
B. "Development" does not include:
1. Maintenance of existing buildings and facilities such as reroofing or resurfacing roads.
2. Gardening, plowing, and similar agricultural practices that do not involve filling, grading, or
construction of levees.
3. Agricultural development activities on farms including farm residences as exempted by law.
FPE OR FLOOD PROTECTION ELEVATION: The elevation of the base flood (plus 1 foot) at any
given location in the SFHA.
FLOOD: A general and temporary condition of inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow,
the unusual and rapid accumulation, or the runoff of surface waters from any source.
FLOODWAY: That portion of the SFHA required to store and convey the base flood. If not prohibited,
building or placing obstructions in a floodway will increase flood damages to other properties.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 451/460
SFHA OR SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREA: Those lands within the jurisdiction of the city of Marion
that are subject to inundation by the base flood. The SFHAs of the city of Marion are generally
identified as such on the flood insurance rate map of the city prepared by the federal insurance
administration and dated September 15, 1983, as the effective date. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd.
2013 Code)
13-1-4: BASE FLOOD ELEVATION:
The protection standard of this chapter is the base flood according to the best data available to the
Illinois state water survey's floodplain information repository. Whenever a party disagrees with the best
available data, he may finance the detailed engineering study needed to replace existing data with
better data and submit it to the state water survey.
A. The base flood elevation for the SFHAs of the following streams:
Campground Creek
Crab Orchard Creek
East Fork Campground Creek
Fairground Creek
High School Tributary
Mule Creek
North Fork High School Tributary
North Fork Westend Creek
West Fork Campground Creek
West Fork Westernaire Creek
Westend Creek
Westernaire Creek
shall be delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the flood insurance study of the city prepared
by the federal insurance administration and dated March 15, 1983.
B. The base flood elevation for each SFHA delineated as an AH zone/AO zone shall be that elevation
delineated on the flood insurance rate map of the city.
C. The base flood elevation for each of the remaining SFHAs delineated as an A zone on the flood
insurance rate map shall be the 100-year flood depth calculated by the Illinois state water survey
according to the formulas presented in "Depth & Frequency Of Floods In Illinois", published by the
U.S. Geological Survey, 1976. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-5: DEVELOPMENT PERMIT:
A. Permit And Compliance Required: No person, firm, corporation, or governmental body not
exempted by law shall commence any development in the SFHA without first obtaining a
development permit from the code enforcement officer. The code enforcement officer shall not
issue a development permit if the proposed development does not meet the requirements of this
chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 452/460
B. Application For Permit: Application for a development permit shall be made on a form provided by
the code enforcement officer. The application shall be accompanied by drawings of the site, drawn
to scale, showing property line dimensions and those parts of the site that are below the base flood
elevation. For those parts below the base food elevation, the drawing shall also show: (Ord. 1033,
9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
1. Existing grade elevations and all changes in grade resulting from excavation or filling;
2. The direction of flow of surface drainage and flood flows;
3. The location of all watercourses and drainage facilities;
4. The location and dimensions of all buildings and additions to buildings; and
5. The elevation of the lowest floor, including basement, of all buildings subject to the requirements
of section 13-1-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
C. Review Of Application: Upon receipt of an application for a development permit, the code
enforcement officer shall compare the elevation of the site to the base flood elevation. Any
development located on land higher than the base flood elevation is not in the SFHA and,
therefore, not subject to the requirements of this chapter.
D. Additional Required Permits: The code enforcement officer shall inform the applicant of any and all
other local, state, and federal permits that may be required for this type of development activity.
The development permit will only be issued on the condition that the other specified permits are
obtained. The code enforcement officer shall not issue a use permit or occupancy permit unless all
required permits have been obtained. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
13-1-6: PREVENTING INCREASED FLOOD HEIGHTS AND DAMAGES:
A. 1. No development in the SFHA shall create a damaging or potentially damaging increase in flood
heights or velocity. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
2. For development proposals located in an identified floodway or within a riverine SFHA where the
floodway has not yet been identified, the following rule shall apply: The code enforcement officer
shall review the development plans to discern if: (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
a. A new obstruction to flood flow would be created;
b. The project will involve a channel crossing such as a bridge or pipeline; or
c. The project will modify the shape of the channel. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
If any of these three (3) situations will result from the project, the applicant shall be required to
obtain a permit from the Illinois department of natural resources, issued pursuant to 615
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/23. The code enforcement officer shall not issue a development
permit unless the applicant has obtained either a section 5/23 permit or a "waiver of permit
required" from the department of natural resources. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
3. For development proposals located in a flood fringe, AO zone, or AH zone, identified as such on
an SFHA map or in a lakefront floodplain, ponding area, area of sheet flow, or other SFHA not
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 453/460
subject to overbank flooding from an identified channel, the requirements of this subsection shall
not apply.
B. No development in the SFHA shall include locating or storing chemicals, explosives, buoyant
materials, flammable liquids, pollutants, or other hazardous or toxic materials below the FPE
unless such materials are stored in a storage tank or floodproofed building constructed according
to the requirements of subsection 13-1-7B3 of this chapter.
C. New and replacement sanitary sewer lines and on site waste disposal systems may be permitted,
provided all manholes or other aboveground openings located below the FPE are watertight. (Ord.
1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-7: PROTECTING BUILDINGS:
A. Application Of Provisions: In addition to the damage prevention requirements of section 13-1-6 of
this chapter, all buildings to be located in the SFHA shall be protected from flood damage below
the FPE. This building protection requirement applies to the following situations:
1. Construction or placement of a new building valued at more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00);
2. Improvements made to an existing building that increase the first floor area by more than twenty
percent (20%);
3. Reconstruction or repairs made to a damaged building that are valued at or more than fifty
percent (50%) of the value of the building before the damage occurred; and
4. Installing a mobile home on a new site or a new mobile home on an existing site. This building
protection requirement does not apply to returning a mobile home to the same site it formerly
lawfully occupied.
B. This building protection requirement may be met by any one of the following methods:
1. A building may be constructed on permanent landfill in accordance with the following:
a. The area to be filled shall be cleared of all standing trees, brush, down timber, trash, and other
growth or objects unsuitable for use as foundation material.
b. The fill shall be placed in layers no greater than one foot (1') deep before compaction.
c. The surface of the fill shall be at or above the FPE. The fill shall extend at least ten feet (10')
beyond the foundation of the building before sloping below the FPE.
d. The fill shall be protected against erosion and scour during flooding by vegetative cover, rip
rap, or bulkheading. If vegetative cover is used, the slopes shall be no steeper than three
horizontal to one vertical (3:1).
e. The fill shall not adversely affect the flow of surface drainage from or onto neighboring
properties.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 454/460
f. The bottom of the lowest floor, including joists, if any, and all utility meters shall be located at
or above the FPE. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
g. The code enforcement officer shall maintain a record of the as built elevation of the lowest
floor of the building. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
2. A building may be elevated in accordance with the following:
a. The building or improvements shall be elevated on stilts, piles, walls, crawl space, or other
foundation that is permanently open to floodwaters and not subject to damage by hydrostatic
pressures.
b. The foundation and supporting members shall be anchored, shaped and aligned so as to
minimize exposure to known hydrodynamic forces such as current, waves, and floating debris.
c. Mobile homes shall not be permitted in the SFHA.
d. All areas below the FPE shall be constructed of materials resistant to flood damage. The
bottom of the lowest floor, including joists, if any, and all utility meters shall be located at or
above the FPE. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
e. The code enforcement officer shall maintain a record of the as built elevation of the lowest
floor. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
f. No area below the FPE shall be used for storage of items or materials subject to flood damage
unless such items or materials are declared "property not covered" by a standard flood
insurance policy of the national flood insurance program. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
g. Any future alteration of the area below the FPE that violates the requirements of this
subsection B2 shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. The code enforcement officer shall
inform the applicant that such alteration is considered a wilful act to increase flood damages
and, therefore, will cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended.
(Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
h. No mobile home may be placed on a new site located within an identified floodway.
3. A nonresidential building may be floodproofed in accordance with the following:
a. A registered professional engineer shall certify that the building has been designed so that
below the FPE, the structure and attendant utility facilities are watertight and capable of
resisting the effects of the base flood. The building design shall take into account flood
velocities, duration, rate of rise, hydrostatic and hydrodynamic forces, the effects of buoyancy,
and impacts from debris or ice.
b. Floodproofing measures shall be operable without human intervention and without an outside
source of electricity. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
c. The code enforcement officer shall maintain the engineer's certificate and a record of the as
built elevation to which the building was floodproofed. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013
Code)
13-1-8: OTHER DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 455/460
A. The city council shall take into account flood hazards, to the extent that they are known, in all
official actions related to land management, use and development. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
B. The city council shall not approve any annexation agreement or plat of subdivision located outside
the corporate limits unless such agreement or plat is in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. The code enforcement officer shall obtain the best available SFHA maps and data for the
unincorporated area.
C. New subdivisions, mobile home parks, and planned unit developments (PUDs) shall meet the
requirements of sections 13-1-6 and 13-1-7 of this chapter. Plats or plans for new subdivisions,
mobile home parks, and planned unit developments (PUDs) shall include a signed statement by a
registered professional engineer that the plat or plans account for changes in the drainage of
surface waters in accordance with the plat act1. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
D. Plats or plans for new subdivisions, mobile home parks, and planned unit developments (PUDs)
shall display the following flood data:
1. The boundary of the SFHA;
2. The boundary of the floodway, if shown on available SFHA maps;
3. Easements of lands dedicated to the city for access for channel maintenance purposes; and
4. The FPE for each building site. Where the base flood elevation is not available from an existing
study filed with the state water survey, the applicant shall be responsible for submitting it to the
state water survey for review and approval as best available elevation data. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-
1983)
E. Plans for the development activities to be undertaken by the city in the SFHA shall be reviewed by
the code enforcement officer to ensure that they comply with this chapter. Except as exempted by
law, no other local government shall commence any development activity in the SFHA without first
obtaining a development permit from the code enforcement officer. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd.
2013 Code)
F. The city plan commission shall take the following into consideration when preparing or revising the
comprehensive plan, community development program, housing assistance plan, and other land
use or development programs:
1. Preserving SFHA land for open space uses such as farming or recreation;
2. Acquiring and removing frequently flooded buildings;
3. Prohibiting hospitals, water treatment plants, natural gas storage and other critical or especially
hazardous facilities from locating in the SFHA;
4. Identifying the elevations of the base flood and past floods at entrances to public buildings, on
street signs, or other prominent locations; and
5. Other flood hazard mitigation or floodplain management activities that could help accomplish the
purposes of this chapter. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 456/460
13-1-9: VARIANCES:
A. Authority: Whenever the standards of this chapter place undue hardship on a specific development
proposal, the applicant may apply to the city plan commission for a variance. The plan commission
shall review the applicant's request for a variance and shall submit its recommendation to the city
council.
B. Standards For Variance Request: No variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates
that:
1. The development activity cannot be located outside the SFHA;
2. A substantial economic hardship would result if the variance were not granted;
3. The relief requested is the minimum necessary;
4. There will be no additional threat to public health or safety or creation of a nuisance;
5. There will be no additional public expense for flood protection, rescue or relief operations,
policing or repairs to roads, utilities, or other public facilities; and
6. The provisions of subsection 13-1-5D of this chapter can still be met. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
C. Variances From Specific Provisions:
1. The code enforcement officer shall notify an applicant in writing that a variance from the
requirements of section 13-1-7 of this chapter that would lessen the degree of protection to a
building will: (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
a. Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as twenty five
dollars ($25.00) for one hundred dollars ($100.00) of insurance coverage;
b. Increase the risk to life and property; and
c. Require that the applicant proceed with knowledge of these risks and that he will acknowledge
in writing that he assumes the risk and liability.
2. A variance from the requirements of section 13-1-7 of this chapter may be granted to permit a
"wet floodproofed" building, that is, a building to be intentionally flooded during a flood, provided:
a. No part of such a building below the FPE may be subject to flood damage.
b. The variance shall be conditioned on the contents being:
(1) Of materials resistant to flood damage; or
(2) Items declared "property not covered" by a standard flood insurance policy of the national
flood insurance program. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
c. Any future alteration of the area below the FPE that violates the conditions of the variance
shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. The code enforcement officer shall inform the
applicant that any such alteration is considered a wilful act to increase flood damages and,
therefore, will cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 457/460
D. Historic Landmarks: Variances requested in connection with restoration of a site or building
documented as worthy of preservation by the Illinois department of natural resources may be
granted using criteria more permissive than the requirements of subsection B of this section. (Ord.
1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
13-1-10: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory
purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of
study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes.
This chapter does not imply that development either inside or outside of the SFHA will be free from
flooding or damage. This chapter does not create liability on the part of the city or any officer or
employee thereof for any flood damage that results from reliance on this chapter or any administrative
decision made lawfully hereunder. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-11: ABROGATION AND GREATER RESTRICTIONS:
This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed
restrictions. However, where this chapter and other ordinance, easement, covenant, or deed
restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. (Ord.
1033, 9-12-1983)
13-1-12: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
A. Violation: Failure to comply with the requirements of a permit or conditions of a variance resolution
shall be deemed to be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
B. Determination And Notice Of Violation; Injunction: The code enforcement officer may determine,
upon due investigation, that a violation of this chapter exists, and after the owner fails, after ten
(10) days' notice, to correct his property, the city may make application to the circuit court for an
injunction requiring conformance with this chapter or make such other order as the court sees
necessary to secure compliance herewith.
C. Penalty: Any person who violates this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as provided
in section 1-4-1 of this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983; amd. 2013 Code)
D. Other Remedies; Costs: Nothing herein shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action to
prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall accrue to the person or
persons responsible. (Ord. 1033, 9-12-1983)
Chapter 2
STORMWATER DETENTION
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 458/460
13-2-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
A. The growth in and around the city and the associated development and construction of buildings,
paved surfaces, roads and other improvements have altered in the past and continue to alter the
natural flow of surface waters on the land, which, together with the construction of gutters, culverts,
drains and channels for the carrying off of surface waters, have both increased the quantity of
stormwater and amplified the peak flow rates of runoff, thus leading to present and potential
flooding of property and homes, dangerous flows within and over public roadways and streets, and
soil and channel erosion.
B. It is the intention of the city council to protect the health and safety of the citizens and visitors of the
community and to prevent damage to private property and public facilities through the proper
design and construction of both on site and regional stormwater detention facilities that prevent or
adequately reduce increases in peak flow rates of runoff that may otherwise increase the risk of
flooding and associated risk of public endangerment, property damage and erosion.
C. It is the intention of the city council, through this chapter, to establish a water detention pond
program for the design and construction of stormwater detention facilities so that, where practical,
the most cost effective protection from flooding may be accomplished.
D. It is the intention of the city council to protect the health and safety of the citizens of and visitors to
the community and to prevent damage to private property and public facilities through the
installation and use of temporary and permanent erosion control practices that prevent or
adequately reduce increases in erosion and siltation that may otherwise increase the risk of
flooding and the associated risk of public endangerment and property damage by clogging and/or
partial filling of constructed or natural drainageways as well as drainage structures and detention
ponds. (Ord. 2212, 7-14-2008)
13-2-2: APPLICATION AND JURISDICTION:
A. This chapter shall apply to all property within the corporate city limits and the one and one-half
(11/2) mile zoning jurisdiction by the city.
B. Subsection 13-2-3B and section 13-2-5 of this chapter shall not apply to:
1. Single-family or duplex residential lots of subdivisions approved prior to the effective date
hereof, unless specifically required by prior agreement between the city and the owners or
developers of such subdivisions, or to new one or two (2) lot subdivisions for single-family or
duplex residential lots, and this chapter is intended to be implemented for entire subdivisions at
the time of platting and construction of streets and drainage improvements and not on an
individual lot basis for single-family and duplex residential subdivisions.
2. Residential lots in the nonsubdivided areas that create no more impervious ground cover than
twenty percent (20%) of the gross lot surface area exclusive of any area within the 100-year
floodplain. (Ord. 2212, 7-14-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 459/460
13-2-3: STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS:
A. It is prohibited to place fill material or construct impervious cover or construct or place any other
structure on a person's property or perform any excavation or grading in a manner which alters the
flow of surface water across said property in a manner which damages any adjacent property.
No final subdivision plat, subdivision construction plan, or site plan shall be approved by the city
unless it can be demonstrated by the owner or developer of such property that the proposed
development will not result in damage to any adjacent or downstream property. This will be
certified by a professional engineer's submittal of sufficient data and calculations.
B. The requirement of subsection A of this section shall be accomplished through one of the following
means: Design and construction of an on site stormwater detention facility or facilities by the
landowner or developer which limits the peak flood flows from the proposed development to the
existing peak flood flows from the subject tract.
C. Acceptance of requests from the landowner or developer to meet the stormwater detention
requirements through measures listed in subsections A and B of this section is solely at the
discretion of the city and shall not relieve the owner of responsibility under civil law to adjacent and
downstream properties.
D. Acceptance by the city of on site stormwater detention plans will be based on the suitability and
adequacy of the engineering and technical design of the proposed stormwater detention facility, as
described in section 13-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2212, 7-14-2008)
13-2-4: ENGINEERING AND TECHNICAL DESIGN:
A. A registered professional engineer, licensed in the state of Illinois and qualified and experienced in
the design and operation of stormwater detention ponds and related stormwater management
facilities, shall perform the hydraulic and structural design of stormwater detention ponds and
related stormwater management facilities, including the development of engineering and technical
information required for evaluation by the city.
B. Any design for stormwater detention shall adhere to the planning and design drainage criteria
adopted by the city engineer and approved by the city council as attached to the ordinance codified
herein and made a part hereof. Such criteria will be available for copy at the office of the city
engineer and the office of the city code enforcement officer.
C. All design and technical information necessary to thoroughly evaluate the suitability and adequacy
of the engineering and technical design of proposed on site stormwater detention facilities and, if
proposed, off site facilities, shall be provided to the city for review. All detention and runoff
calculations, including computer model simulations, if used, shall be provided.
D. All on site stormwater detention facilities shall be designed to adequately and safely pass all
stormwater inflows, including flood flows and runoff from upstream and adjacent properties that
have natural and/or existing overland flows toward and onto the subject tract. The on site
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=972 460/460
stormwater detention facilities should not impound stormwater onto or cause backwater to
inundate any upstream or adjacent properties in excess of existing conditions.
E. On site stormwater detention facilities shall not be placed such that they encroach into the
regulatory 100-year floodplain as established by the city, and/or the federal emergency
management agency, unless it can be satisfactorily demonstrated to the city through the use of
hydraulic modeling that such encroachment will not cause any rise in the 100-year flood level on
other off site properties or that the increase in the 100-year flood level caused by such
encroachment will occur entirely on site on the owner's or developer's property.
F. Additional engineering and technical rules and guidance with respect to the application and review
of the stormwater detention requirements of this chapter may be provided by the city. (Ord. 2212,
7-14-2008)
13-2-5: PENALTIES:
A. Failure to comply with the terms of this chapter shall result in the denial of all city building and
related permits and refusal to accept dedication of a plat when proffered.
B. Violation of the terms of this chapter may subject the violator to a fine as provided in section 1-4-1
of this code. (Ord. 2212, 7-14-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
